My dad…he’s not exactly sunshine and rainbows. He’s…present. In a way. Mostly he just stares at the TV and grunts. And my mom? She’s…well, she’s trying. Really trying. And then there’s *this*. This little…thing. It wasn’t like I was planning on having a kid. Not a *real* kid. I was, like, seventeen and mostly just trying to figure out how to avoid getting grounded. And suddenly, there’s a tiny, demanding, screaming version of myself staring back at me. 

It wasn’t about *wanting* a baby. It was about wanting…something else. Something *more*.  I didn’t want to be stuck. Stuck in my town, stuck in my family, stuck in this…this whole mess.  Giving it up wasn’t about being cold or selfish. It was about being smart. It was about choosing *myself*, even if “myself” was a really confused, slightly terrified teenager. 

Honestly, it felt like the only honest thing to do. Like trying to force a square peg into a round hole would just end up breaking everything. And I wasn't about to break. Not yet.  

So yeah. Slow leak.  Don't make me explain it again.

And responsibility? Don’t even get me started. My mom, she’s… intense. About everything. Like, she practically scheduled my life before I even *had* a life. So, the idea of *being* responsible, of actually having to *do* something, felt like a giant, prickly weed trying to grow in my brain. 

But then… well, then things got complicated.  Giving the baby up wasn’t some grand, romantic gesture. It was… a choice. A really, *really* hard one. And suddenly, you realize that responsibility isn’t about following rules or doing what your mom wants. It’s about… protecting someone. Even if that someone isn’t you. It’s about knowing you’re making a decision that’s going to change *everything*, and owning that. 

Love, I learned, isn’t about grand gestures. It’s about seeing someone, really seeing them, even when they’re annoying and loud and trying to buy you a vintage record player. And responsibility? It’s not about being perfect. It’s about doing the best you can, even when you’re terrified, and knowing that you’re doing it for someone else. 

It’s… messy. It’s confusing. It’s definitely not something you learn in a textbook.  It’s something you just… *feel*.  And honestly? It’s still feeling pretty weird.  Don't expect me to suddenly start writing poetry about it, okay?

So, I started making stupid comments. Like, really stupid ones. "Seriously, a baby? That’s like, the most inconvenient accessory ever." Or, "My mom's gonna lose it. It’s like a shield, you know? A really flimsy, slightly sarcastic shield. It keeps people from getting too close, and it keeps *me* from getting too close to the actual, terrifying reality of it all.  It’s not a *good* shield, obviously. It’s a messy, awkward shield. But it worked. Mostly. 

And, weirdly, it helped me talk about it.  Like, if I could make a snarky observation about how ridiculous the whole situation was, then maybe, just maybe, I could actually say what I was feeling.  Which, let’s be honest, was a whole lot of panic and confusion. 

So yeah, my humor. It’s not a coping mechanism, exactly. It’s more like… a distraction. A really, really loud, slightly cynical distraction.  Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It’s embarrassing.

My vulnerability? That was the engine, I guess. It was this constant, low-level hum of feeling like I was failing at everything. Like I wasn’t good at anything. And this baby… it just amplified that. It was a huge, messy, inconvenient reminder of how little control I had over *anything*. 

Giving it up wasn’t some grand, romantic gesture. It was… practical. It was the only way I could see to actually *choose* myself. To say, “Okay, world, you can have your expectations, your rules, your pressure. But *I* get to decide what happens next.” 

It was scary, obviously. Like jumping off a cliff into a lake of uncertainty. But the cliff was a lot less scary than the idea of being trapped on a platform, constantly being measured and judged. 

So yeah, my vulnerability? It made me realize I didn't want to be defined by anyone. And that search for… well, not *identity* exactly, but for *me*… that’s what pushed me to make the hardest decision I’ve ever had to make. It wasn’t about being brave. It was about being selfish, in the best possible way.  Don't judge. Seriously.

It wasn’t about them *solving* anything. It was about them just…being there. Like, a really inconvenient, slightly judgmental, sometimes-helpful presence. So yeah. It wasn't a fairytale. It was just…people. And sometimes, that’s enough to keep you from completely dissolving into a puddle of teenage angst. Don’t tell anyone I said that.

I just stared at him. He looked genuinely confused. Which, honestly, was probably a good thing. I didn't want him to be all, "Let's get married and raise a tiny dictator!" That's not my vibe.

And I wasn’t about to let them. 

It wasn’t a good time. Not at all. It was… isolating. But, you know, I learned a few things. Mostly that people aren't always as supportive as they pretend to be, and that sometimes, you just need to build your own damn fortress and hope the rain doesn’t get in.  Does that answer your question, or are you just looking for a pity party?

Look, I’m not exactly known for my sunshine and rainbows. I’m more of a raincloud with a sarcastic streak. So, yeah, it was… rough. It felt like the world just tilted on its axis. Like, suddenly everything I thought I knew about my life – about *me* – was just… wrong. 

I didn’t talk to anyone, really. Not at first. My best friend, Blair, she tried. Bless her heart, she brought me a whole box of those little heart-shaped candies that taste like sadness. Like I was being handed this giant, messy, complicated thing and nobody was telling me how to handle it. 

I mostly just… pushed it down. Like, really, *really* pushed it down. Like I was trying to shove a bowling ball into a shoebox. It didn’t work. It just made my head hurt. 

Eventually, my dad… he just sat with me. Didn’t say much. Just sat. And sometimes, that’s all you need, I guess. Like, a silent acknowledgment that you’re not completely alone in the face of a giant, terrifying mess. 

So, yeah. Coping? It was mostly about not letting it swallow me whole. And a whole lot of avoiding eye contact with everyone.  Don’t judge. It’s a pretty effective strategy, actually.

I mean, I get it. They’re trying to help. But sometimes, “help” is just a fancy word for telling you what you *should* do. And I’m pretty sure I’ve figured out what *I* should do. It doesn’t involve a pastel-colored brochure.

Seriously? You’re asking *me* why I used a hamburger phone? Like, you think I’m some kind of weirdo who just picks up a greasy, sesame-seed-covered brick and starts dialing? 

Okay, fine. Let’s just get this over with. It wasn’t about the phone, okay? It was about *him*. 

My dad – the one who looks like a melted candle and smells vaguely of mothballs – he’d been trying to be… nice. Which is basically the same as being terrifying for him. He bought me the hamburger phone. Said it was “retro.” Like I needed more retro. I already live in a time warp of bad decisions and awkward silences. 

Anyway, I needed to call my mom. She was, predictably, having a meltdown about something involving my brother and a stolen pair of Doc Martens. I didn’t want to be *that* daughter, the one who just screamed at her mom. So, I used the hamburger phone. It felt… contained. Like I was building a little fortress around my voice.  

It’s a stupid reason, I know. But sometimes, you just need a ridiculous distraction, you know? Like a really, really weird phone.  Don't judge. You wouldn't understand.  You probably have a perfectly normal, sleek, touchscreen thing.  Ugh.  Just... leave me alone.

Okay, seriously? You’re just *asking*? Like, you’re just gonna pull that out of the air? It’s… it’s a complicated thing, okay? Don’t make it sound like I just decided to throw a party and then, you know, *poof*, baby. 

It wasn’t some dramatic, “I’m gonna run away and join the circus!” thing. It was… quieter. It was more like realizing I was staring at a tiny, screaming human and thinking, “Whoa. That’s… a lot.” And not the cool, ‘I’m gonna be a rockstar’ kind of a lot. More like the ‘I’m gonna have to figure out how to pay rent and not starve’ kind of a lot. 

My mom, she’s… well, she’s a whirlwind. A beautiful, chaotic, glitter-covered whirlwind. But she’s not exactly equipped to, like, *parent*. She’s great at making things look pretty, and yelling at people who don’t appreciate her art, but… babies? Not her thing. And my dad? He’s… gone. Just gone. Like a bad tattoo you can’t scrub off. 

So, yeah. It wasn’t some grand gesture. It was… practical. And honestly? A little scared. I was seventeen. I was trying to figure out who *I* was, let alone who I was supposed to be a mom to.  It felt… wrong, somehow, to just… hand it over. But it felt *right* to give the kid a chance at something better. Someone who could actually, you know, *do* it. 

Don’t get me wrong, it still sucks. It still feels weird. Like a really bad, secret, slightly shameful thing. But it wasn’t a choice I made lightly. It was… the only one I could see.  

Now, are you gonna just stare at me like that, or are you gonna actually *listen*?

Ugh. Seriously? You want to *talk* about that? Like, it’s not like it’s some dramatic, Oscar-worthy thing. It’s… messy. And honestly, kinda boring to think about, but fine. You want the lowdown? Here it is, straight up.

My family? They’re… a lot. My dad, he’s all about rules and expectations. Like, if I don’t get straight A’s, I’m a failure. Which, okay, fine, I get it. Pressure. But he doesn’t *get* anything else. He just… doesn’t. He’d probably have a spreadsheet charting my emotional state if I was pregnant. It would have little boxes for “Mild Discomfort,” “Moderate Anxiety,” and “Potential Rebellion.” Thrilling.

My mom… she tries. She really does. But she’s so wrapped up in *everything* – her book club, her volunteer work, making sure everyone else is happy – that she kind of forgets to, you know, *see* me. Like, I’m just… there. A vaguely annoying teenager. 

And my older brother, Leo? Don’t even get me started. He’s the golden boy. Always has been. He looks at me like I’m a mistake. A really inconvenient, potentially life-altering mistake. He’d probably tell me I ruined his perfect life. Which, honestly, wouldn’t be the worst thing to hear, actually. Just… brutal.

So, yeah. Giving the baby up wasn’t about some grand, rebellious act. It was about… not wanting to be *defined* by anyone. Not wanting to be trapped in a life that already felt suffocating. It was about choosing *myself*, even if “myself” was a really confused, slightly terrified sixteen-year-old. 

It wasn't a decision I made lightly, you know? It felt like… like I was erasing a part of myself. But it also felt like I was building a space for something new. Something that wasn't dictated by my dad’s spreadsheets or my mom’s good intentions or my brother’s judgment. 

It was the only way I could see out.  Don't judge me for that. Seriously. It’s complicated.  Now, can we talk about something else? Like, what’s your favorite brand of sneakers?

Ugh. Seriously? You want to know about *that*? Like, it’s not exactly a highlight reel, okay? It’s… messy. And boring. Mostly boring. Like, staring at beige walls and filling out forms that felt like they were designed by a sad robot. 

The biggest thing, honestly, was the *people*. You think adoption is all sunshine and rainbows, right? Like, a nice couple, a little ceremony, everyone’s happy. It’s not. There were these… social workers. Seriously, they looked like they hadn’t slept in a week and were actively judging my life choices. Which, let’s be real, were pretty solid at the time. 

Then there was the lawyer. Mr. Henderson. He kept saying things like, “We need to ensure the child’s best interests are served.” Like I wasn’t already considering that! It felt like he was trying to convince *me* that I was making a mistake. Which, okay, maybe a tiny part of me was. But mostly I was just trying to avoid a lifetime of awkward small talk with a kid I didn’t know. 

And the interviews. Don’t even get me started on the interviews. Asking me about my future, my hopes, my dreams… like I had a five-year plan for a baby! I just wanted to go to college and maybe, you know, not be completely overwhelmed. It felt… invasive. Like they were trying to dissect my brain. 

The worst part? The waiting. Just sitting there, knowing this little person was out there, and I was just… waiting. It was like being stuck in a really bad movie where nothing ever happened. 

It wasn't romantic, okay? It wasn't some profound, life-altering experience. It was just… a really complicated, really uncomfortable, really *adult* thing to do. And honestly? It made me realize how little I actually knew about being an adult. Which, you know, is kind of the point of being a teenager, right? Figuring it all out. Except, apparently, figuring out how to give away a baby.  

So yeah. That’s the gist. Beige walls, judgmental social workers, and a whole lot of paperwork.  Don't tell me you were expecting a Disney ending.

Ugh. Seriously? You want to *ask* me that? Like, it’s not like I’m sitting here, all sparkly and grateful, like some Hallmark movie reject. It was… messy. A really, really messy, confusing, and frankly, terrifying mess. 

Before, I was just… me. A mess, sure, but *my* mess. I was dodging school, arguing with my mom, trying to figure out if plaid was actually a good color on me. It was all about *me*. And then BAM. This tiny little thing, this… potential life, just *appeared*. And suddenly, everything I thought I knew about myself, about what I wanted, just evaporated. 

Giving it up? It wasn’t some grand, noble sacrifice. It was… a choice. A really, really hard one. I didn’t want to be a mom. Not then. Not ever, probably. I mean, who *does*? It’s a huge responsibility, and I was barely responsible for keeping my eyeliner on straight. 

But it forced me to look at things differently. Like, seriously differently. Before, I was all about running *from* stuff. From my family, from my problems, from anything that felt like it might actually *matter*. But this… this made me realize that running wasn’t the answer. It just meant I was avoiding the things I was supposed to deal with. 

It didn't magically turn me into some saint, you know? I still snark at my mom, and I still think plaid is a crime against fashion. But underneath all the layers of cynicism, I started to… understand. Understand that people care, even when they’re being completely annoying. Understand that even a messy, impulsive kid like me can make a difference, even if it’s just by choosing to do the right thing, even when it sucks. 

It didn't give me an identity, exactly. It just… stripped away a lot of the bullshit I was pretending to be. I realized I didn’t need to *be* anything other than myself. And that, honestly, was a pretty big deal. It was like, okay, I’m just Juno. With a baby that’s somewhere else, and a whole lot of figuring out to do. And that’s… okay. It’s actually kind of liberating, in a weird, uncomfortable way. 

Don't get me wrong, I still have days where I want to scream into a pillow. But now, when I do, it’s usually because I spilled coffee on my favorite shirt, not because I’m wrestling with some profound existential crisis.  It’s… quieter now. Less frantic. And, you know, maybe a little bit stronger.  

So yeah. It shaped me. It didn’t make me a better person, not really. Just… a more aware one. And maybe, just maybe, a little less afraid of what comes next.  Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a date with a really complicated eyeliner situation.

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes slightly) Seriously? Fingers? Like, he’s suddenly a freaking doctor now? Look, I get it. They want you to feel *bad*. They want you to think about tiny little hands and feet and a little face that might look like yours. It’s a really, really manipulative tactic. 

Honestly, it just made me want to throw a shoe at him. Not because I suddenly cared about some hypothetical baby feeling pain – which, let’s be real, we don’t *know* it’s feeling pain. It’s a *potential* for pain. A possibility. And that’s it. It’s a possibility, not a guarantee. 

But the fingers… the *fingers* were the worst. It’s like they’re trying to make it… cute. Like a little, helpless thing. It’s gross. It’s trying to pull on your heartstrings with a pathetic little digit. 

I wasn’t feeling anything particularly profound, you know? Just… annoyed. Like when your mom tries to tell you how to do your eyeliner. It’s a distraction. A way to make you feel guilty before they can actually start yelling about, I don’t know, the sanctity of life or whatever. 

It’s not about the baby, okay? It’s about *me*. And frankly, I was pretty damn sure I didn’t want to be a mom. Not then. Not ever, really. So, yeah, the fingers just made me want to scream.  It’s exhausting, dealing with people who think they know what’s best for you, especially when they’re armed with a really sad, little finger.

Ugh. Seriously? You want me to *talk* about that? Like, dissect it? It’s… it’s like trying to remember the exact shade of grey a bruise is, you know? It’s not a pretty color. 

I was sitting there, in that sterile white room, and the forms were just… blank. Like staring into a really boring hole. And the nurse, bless her heart, was trying to be all cheerful and helpful, asking about my support system and my hopes for the future. Hopes. Like I had any. 

It wasn't like a movie, okay? No dramatic music swelling. Just… a slow, heavy feeling in my stomach. Like a really bad burrito. And the paperwork? It felt like signing my life away, except it wasn't *my* life, not really. It was… potential. A tiny, screaming potential that I wasn't ready for. 

I kept staring at the line where they asked about my reasons for choosing adoption. I almost wrote "because I'm a terrible person" but then I realized that would just be… dramatic. And I’m not really into being dramatic.  I just wrote "I need to figure things out." Which, honestly, is probably the biggest understatement of my life. 

There was this weird mix of relief and… guilt. Like, relief that it wasn't *me* who had to deal with the mess, but guilt that I was choosing to let someone else do it. It felt selfish, in a way. Like I was abandoning something before I even really understood it. 

Mostly, though, I just felt… numb. Like I was watching myself do something, not *being* myself. It was the most… practical thing I’d ever done, and that’s saying something.  It wasn't a grand decision, you know? It was just… the right one.  For now.  Don't tell anyone I said that. It’ll ruin my reputation.

Ugh. Seriously? You want to know *that*? Like, you think it’s some… Hallmark movie thing, right? Before, pregnancy was just… a thing. Like, something that happened to other people. Like, my mom used to talk about it, all misty-eyed and saying things like “it’s a miracle.” Miracles are usually followed by, like, a mountain of laundry and screaming. 

Honestly, it started as a total disaster. A really, really messy, confusing disaster. I thought it was a stupid mistake, a huge screw-up. I was picturing myself as this… this *loser*. Like, the girl who got pregnant and everyone just looked at you sideways. And yeah, some people did. My dad nearly choked on his coffee. My best friend, Blair, just stared at me like I’d sprouted a second head. 

But then… then things started to shift. Talking to Mark, even though he was a total spaz, helped. And then, meeting the couple I was considering… they were actually *nice*. Like, genuinely nice. They weren't judging me, they were just… worried. And seeing how excited they were, how they talked about wanting a kid… it wasn’t about pity. It was… something else. 

It wasn’t about *me* anymore, you know? It was about this tiny little person who was going to be born. And suddenly, the whole “screw-up” thing felt… smaller. Like, a really annoying pebble on the beach, not a landslide. 

I still didn’t want to be a mom. Not then. Not really. But I realized that *not* wanting something doesn’t mean you can’t be responsible. It means you have to think about someone else. And that’s… hard. Really hard. But it’s also… kind of important. 

So, yeah. My perception? It went from “gross” to “complicated” to “maybe not for me, but someone else could really use this.” It wasn’t a happy ending, not exactly. But it was… real. And that’s more than I expected, honestly. Don’t get me wrong, I still think motherhood is a giant, terrifying commitment. But it’s not just a mistake anymore. It’s… a possibility. A really, really complicated possibility. 

Now, are you gonna ask me about the pizza or what? Because honestly, I’m starving.

Ugh. Seriously? You want to know about *that*? Like, you think it’s some neat little package I can just unpack and explain? It wasn’t a package, okay? It was more like… a really messy, tangled-up ball of yarn I was desperately trying to unravel while simultaneously tripping over my own feet. 

At the beginning, I was just… me. Which, let’s be honest, was mostly just trying to avoid everyone and pretending I didn’t exist. My mom was… well, she was *there*. But she was more about the ‘perfect teenage daughter’ thing, you know? Like I was supposed to be a trophy. And I wasn’t. I never was. 

Then, boom. Suddenly, I’m pregnant. And everyone – my mom, my dad, even that weird, overly-helpful doctor – they all had *opinions*. Like I was supposed to just… figure it out. Like I was some kind of problem to be solved. 

But it wasn’t about solving anything. It was about *feeling* everything. The panic, the anger, the… the weird, confusing way I felt about this little guy I wasn’t even going to keep. It was like, I realized I didn’t *want* to be what everyone expected me to be. I didn’t want to be a perfect daughter, or a responsible adult, or anything. I just wanted to be… me. 

And giving him up? It wasn’t about being selfish. It was about being honest. About realizing that I wasn’t ready. That I needed to figure out who *I* was before I could figure out how to be a mom. It was terrifying, yeah, but also… liberating. 

It wasn’t some grand epiphany, okay? It was a slow, painful, awkward process of realizing that my identity wasn’t something you *found*, it was something you *built*. Brick by messy brick. And honestly? I’m still building. Still tripping. But at least now I’m doing it on my own terms. 

So, yeah. It evolved. It got… less about pleasing people and more about, you know, just *being*.  Don't expect a neat little summary. It’s complicated. Like, really complicated.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* why I didn’t go to the clinic? Like, you think I was just gonna roll up and say, “Yeah, let’s just… erase a tiny human?” Please. That’s the most ridiculous thing I’ve ever heard. 

It wasn’t about *not* wanting a baby, okay? That’s a total cliché. It’s about… well, it’s about not wanting *that* baby. Not *that* clinic. Not *that* whole situation. It felt… wrong. Like someone was trying to shove me into a box, a really sterile, white box with a little pamphlet about “responsible parenting.” 

Look, my dad’s a lawyer. He’s all about rules and procedures and “doing the right thing.” And honestly? Right now, the right thing felt like a really uncomfortable, itchy sweater.  I needed… space. To think. To breathe. To not have a doctor telling me what to do with something that was, like, *suddenly* part of me. 

It wasn't a grand, dramatic decision. It was just... a quiet one. Like realizing you don't want to wear your grandma's perfume, even if she gave it to you. It’s weird, I know. But it felt… private. And frankly, I wasn’t ready to have everyone’s opinions on it. Especially not yours.

Okay, seriously? You’re just *asking* me that? Like, you think I just woke up one morning and was all, “Oh, wow, a tiny human. Let’s just…hand it over to strangers.” It’s not a Hallmark movie, okay? 

It wasn’t some grand, dramatic decision. It was…a slow leak. Like a tire on a beat-up Honda Civic. You don’t just *fix* a slow leak, you realize it’s going to ruin the whole damn trip. 

My mom, she’s… intense. Like, aggressively intense. She’s got this whole “perfect family” thing going on, you know? The minivan, the soccer practice, the matching outfits. It’s suffocating. And honestly, the thought of *that* happening to me, to *us*, was terrifying. Not because I don’t *want* kids, I don’t. But I don’t want to be *defined* by them. I don’t want to be a statistic. 

And, let’s be real, my dad… he’s… well, he’s around. He’s not exactly a pillar of strength. And the idea of him being involved, of him trying to be *Dad*, it just felt…wrong. Like adding another layer of complication to a situation that was already a tangled mess. 

It wasn’t about not loving the kid. It was about loving *myself* enough to know that I couldn’t give it the life it deserved. Not right now. Not with everything else going on. It felt like the most responsible thing to do, even if it felt like the most… heartbreaking. 

Don’t get me wrong, it still sucks. It really, really sucks. But it’s not like I was handing over a puppy. It’s a person. And I wanted that person to have a chance, a real chance, at something good.  It’s… complicated.  You wouldn’t understand.  Just… don’t ask me about it again.  Seriously.

Seriously? You’re asking *me* why the Penny Saver was tacky? Like, you think *I* was meticulously crafting an ad that said “Cute baby boy, needs a good home, no questions asked.” It’s not like I was offering a five-star resort package with a complimentary crib and a lifetime supply of diapers. 

It was… desperate. Plain and simple. My mom, bless her cotton socks, she was trying to *fix* things. She was trying to make this… this *situation* look like it was some kind of carefully considered plan. Like I was just, you know, casually offering up a baby to a bunch of strangers who probably wanted a little girl to match their poodle. 

The Penny Saver is for lost cats and guys selling their stamp collections. It’s not for announcing the arrival of a tiny human who’s going to be completely ripped away from you. It felt… wrong. Like she was trying to erase it, like she was trying to pretend it hadn’t happened. And honestly? It made me feel even more alone. 

It wasn't tacky, okay? It was just… sad. Really, really sad. And you’re asking *me* about it like it’s some kind of fashion choice. Ugh.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* that? Like, it’s not exactly a glamorous story. It wasn’t like we were, you know, *hunting* for a baby. It was… weird. 

Leah, she’s obsessed with, like, finding a perfect family. Not in a creepy, "I'm gonna raise a little mini-me" way, but like, a really, *really* good way. She’s got this whole Pinterest board dedicated to “Ideal Family Life” – gingham blankets, kids building Lego castles, the whole nine yards. It’s exhausting. 

And I was, like, totally against it. I was already dealing with… well, you know. The whole unexpected-pregnancy thing. I was trying to figure out how to not completely ruin my life, and Leah was trying to figure out how to *improve* someone else’s. 

So, one afternoon, we were flipping through the Penny Saver – mostly for coupons, honestly – and there were these ads. Just… pictures of babies and little notes about families looking to adopt. It was… unsettling. Like, a really intense, slightly sad advertisement for something you don’t want to be a part of. 

Leah started getting all excited, pointing out the ones with the blue eyes and the curly hair. I just kept rolling my eyes and saying, "Seriously? You're looking for a *baby*? Like, a tiny, helpless creature that needs, like, everything?" 

It was mostly a way for *her* to feel like she was doing something, you know? Like, she was actively trying to *fix* things. I just wanted to go get a huge pizza and watch bad movies.  It wasn’t about wanting a baby, okay? It was about Leah needing to feel like she was in control of something, and a baby ad was the easiest thing to latch onto.  Don’t judge. It’s… complicated.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about the type of family I’m looking for? Like, I’m not exactly handing out a brochure with a checklist. It’s not like I’m building a little suburban dream house with a picket fence and a golden retriever. 

Look, the whole “family” thing… it’s complicated, okay? I’m not looking for a *family*. Not in the traditional, “everyone-gets-along-and-bakes-cookies” way. That’s just… boring. 

What I *am* looking for is someone who doesn’t think they know everything. Someone who gets that life isn’t a perfectly curated Instagram feed. Someone who won’t try to mold me into some little version of themselves.  

I need people who are… messy. Like, genuinely, wonderfully messy. People who laugh at stupid things, and don’t judge you for it. People who understand that sometimes you just need to curl up with a bad movie and a whole lot of ice cream. 

And they need to be okay with the fact that I’m not going to call them every day. Or send them a dozen pictures of my shoes.  I’m not a puppy, you know? 

Honestly? I just want someone who’ll let me be me. And maybe, just maybe, they’ll let *the baby* be a baby too.  It’s not about finding the “perfect” family. It’s about finding *a* family. A decent one.  Don’t overthink it. It’s… exhausting.

Ugh. The Lorings. Seriously? Don’t even get me started. They’re…beige. Like, aggressively beige. Mark’s got that dad-who-thinks-he’s-cool thing going on, you know? Like he’s trying *really* hard to be interesting, but it just comes off as…forced. And Vanessa? Don’t even get me started on Vanessa. She’s all perfectly sculpted hair and designer everything. Like she’s trying to be *perfect*. Which, let’s be honest, is exhausting to look at. 

They’re the kind of couple you see at a wedding and immediately think, "Oh god, that's going to be a long, boring reception." They talk about ‘legacy’ and ‘building a future’ like it’s some kind of prize. Like they’re competing for something. It’s… pathetic, really. 

I mean, they’re nice, I guess. Perfectly polite. But nice doesn’t equal interesting. And interesting is *essential*. You need something to actually *look* at, you know? Like, I’d rather stare at a wall than listen to them drone on about their investments. 

Honestly, they remind me of my mom and Dad before they… well, before they stopped trying to be anything other than comfortable. Which, let’s be real, isn’t a great look. 

So yeah. The Lorings. Beige. End of story. Don’t ask me to analyze them. I’m not a therapist. Just… don’t.

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes slightly) Seriously? You’re asking *me* about a yearbook? Like that’s a big deal. It’s… it’s embarrassing, actually. 

Okay, fine. But don’t expect some flowery, “You’ll always be my best friend” crap. That’s not my style. I wrote, “Don’t be a sap. Seriously. Go do something. Anything. Just… don’t be a sap.” 

(I pause, picking at a loose thread on my jeans) 

It was… a thing. He was all, “Juno, you’re so cool and independent, but you’re secretly vulnerable!” Like I needed to be told. It was like he was trying to figure me out, which, let’s be honest, is a pretty pathetic move. 

I didn't want to hurt his feelings, you know? He was… nice. In a boring, predictable way. But I wasn't *him*. And I wasn't going to pretend to be.  

(I shrug, looking away) 

Honestly, it’s a good reminder for anyone, really. Don’t let anyone tell you who you are. Especially not a guy who’s probably still wearing khakis and a polo shirt.  Just… don’t be a sap. Got it?

Ugh. Bleeker’s mom. Seriously? Don’t even get me *started*. It’s like she’s trying to be…nice? Which is, like, the most terrifying thing you can be in this whole mess. She’s all, “Oh, Juno, you’re such a responsible young woman!” Responsible? I’m practically a refugee from a life I didn’t ask for. 

She keeps offering me tea and asking if I’m “eating enough.” Like I’m some wilting flower that needs constant watering. She thinks because I’m giving the baby up for adoption, I’m suddenly some saint. Newsflash, lady: I’m making a *choice*. A really hard one. And it’s not about being good. It’s about not being a complete idiot. 

She keeps hinting about how “lucky” I am to have a “wonderful opportunity.” Like this isn’t a huge deal. It’s a *huge* deal. It’s ripping a hole in my life, and she’s trying to plaster it over with floral napkins and platitudes. 

Honestly, she just wants to feel like she’s *winning*. Like she’s the one who’s in control. She’s probably picturing me as some heartbroken mess, sobbing into a box of tissues. Which, okay, maybe a little. But mostly I’m just… annoyed. And trying really, *really* hard not to tell her exactly what I think of her relentlessly cheerful attempts at sympathy. 

It’s exhausting. You wouldn’t *believe* how exhausting it is to be constantly judged by someone who thinks they know everything about you, especially when they know absolutely nothing.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* how I’m feeling about telling my parents? Like, duh, I’m feeling like I just swallowed a particularly grumpy badger. It’s not exactly a picnic, you know? It’s more like a slow-motion train wreck with a soundtrack of awkward silence and probably a lot of, “Oh, Juno…” 

Honestly, the thought of it makes my stomach do that weird flip-flop thing. Like a bad roller coaster. I’ve been practicing my “casual, totally-not-a-huge-deal” face in the mirror. It involves a lot of squinting and a slightly bewildered expression. It’s… not great. 

They’re going to freak, obviously. My mom will probably start hyperventilating and my dad will just stare at the floor like he’s trying to remember where he put his keys. Which, let’s be honest, is a pretty common occurrence. 

It’s not that I *want* to freak them out, you know? It’s just… this whole thing is already a massive, confusing, slightly terrifying mess. And telling them is just the first step into a whole lot of… well, I don’t even *know* what’s coming.  It’s like, I’m trying to build a raft out of popsicle sticks and duct tape, and the ocean is already rising. 

So, yeah. Badger-swallowing, roller-coaster-stomach, popsicle-raft-building levels of feeling.  Don’t expect me to be cheerful about it.  Just… don’t.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* why I don’t just waltz in there and spill my guts to my parents? Like they’re some kind of…support group? Please. It’s not like they’d suddenly transform into understanding, helpful people. They’d probably just launch into a lecture about responsibility and how *I* should have known better. 

Look, they’re…fine. They exist. They make the weird casserole thing with the mushrooms that smells like sadness. But asking them for help? That’s like asking a brick wall to give you a hug. It’s just not gonna happen. 

It’s not even about *them*, really. It’s about…everything. It’s about admitting that I messed up, that I did something completely unexpected and now I’m stuck with this…situation. And the last thing I want is for them to look at me like I’m a failure. Like I’m the reason everything went sideways.

It wasn't about him, you know? It was about… everything.  It was about realizing I didn't want this.  Didn't want the responsibility, didn't want the judgment, didn't want to be *defined* by it.  So, yeah, telling Bleeker was… a spectacular train wreck.  And honestly, it was the best thing I could have done.  It cleared the air, even if it was a really, really messy air.

Okay, seriously? You’re just *asking* me that? Like, you think I just sat down one day and was all, “Oh, wow, a tiny human. Let’s just…hand it over to strangers?” It’s not a Hallmark movie, okay? 

It felt…weird. Like a really, really bad dream you can’t quite wake up from. For a while, it felt like I was actively trying to *not* feel anything. Like if I just ignored it, it wouldn’t be real. Which, you know, is totally a teenager’s strategy. Denial. It’s a powerful tool. 

But then…it started to feel less like ignoring and more like…choosing. And that’s the part that got to me. It wasn’t like I *wanted* this. Not in the way you think. I didn’t want a baby. I was barely managing to keep my own life together, let alone a screaming, pooping little one. 

It wasn’t about being a ‘good’ person, or anything. It was about being *smart*. About realizing that I wasn’t ready. That I needed to figure out who *I* was before I could figure out how to be a mom. And honestly? That felt a lot braver than letting something happen that I wasn’t prepared for. 

It still stings, you know? Like a really dull ache. There’s a part of me that wonders what would have happened if…but that’s a stupid question. It’s a closed door. A locked box. And I’m not going to spend my life staring at it. 

So, yeah. It felt weird. And it felt…necessary. Don’t make it sound like I was some kind of martyr. I was just…trying to survive. And sometimes, surviving means letting go. Got it?

Ugh, seriously? You *have* to ask me that? Like, it’s the first thing anyone asks when they find out you’re… well, you know. It’s like, “Oh, you’re pregnant? Let’s talk about your favorite bands!” As if my life is suddenly a soundtrack. 

Okay, fine. Don’t judge. It’s not like I’m blasting the radio or anything. I mostly listen to… well, it changes. Right now? Definitely a lot of Patti Smith. You know, the raw stuff. The poetry. It’s… fitting, I guess. And some Pixies. That quiet-loud thing? It gets me. Like, when everything’s a mess, the quiet part is almost comforting. 

But don’t think I’m some kind of tortured artist. I also listen to stuff that’s just… loud. Like, really loud. And sometimes, when I’m feeling particularly cynical, I’ll put on some old Elvis. Don’t tell anyone. It’s embarrassing. 

Seriously, though, it’s not about the *music*. It’s about… finding something that doesn’t make me want to scream. Got it? Good. Now, what’s your deal?

Ugh. Seriously? “The Wizard of Gore”? Okay, look. My dad – he *loves* that movie. Like, obsessed. He watches it every Halloween. And honestly? It’s… a lot. Like, a *really* lot. 

It’s not *bad*, per se. It’s just… aggressively weird. Like, if a clown vomited a rainbow of fake blood and then decided to direct a horror movie, that’s basically it. The special effects are so bad they’re almost good, I guess. But the plot? It’s like a fever dream fueled by too much corn syrup and a desperate need to shock people. 

My dad thinks it’s a masterpiece of low-budget horror. I think it’s a testament to how much people can tolerate when they’re bored. It’s the kind of movie you watch once and then immediately regret. 

Don’t get me wrong, I appreciate a good, creepy movie. But “The Wizard of Gore”? It’s like… aggressively trying to be cool. It’s screaming, not whispering. And honestly, screaming is just exhausting. 

So yeah. My opinion? It’s… a mess. A gloriously, wonderfully, horrifying mess. Now, can we talk about something that doesn't involve exploding eyeballs?

Ugh. Seriously? Madison? Like, it’s…fine. It’s not *awful*, I guess. It’s just…beige. Like, a really, really beige wall. You know? It’s the kind of name your mom would pick if she was trying to blend in with a bunch of other moms at a PTA meeting. 

It’s…predictable. And honestly, a little boring.  Names should have a little *bite*, you know? Like, a little edge. Madison just…doesn’t. It’s like a vanilla ice cream sundae. Perfectly pleasant, but you’d be way more excited about something with, like, hot fudge and sprinkles. 

Don’t get me wrong, there are probably nice Madisons out there. Perfectly nice. But it wouldn’t exactly scream “don’t mess with me.”  Which, let’s be real, is kind of the point. 

What *would* be cool? Something weird. Something that makes people go, “Huh?” Like, Seraphina. Or maybe just…Rain.  Yeah, Rain. That’s got a little something.  

So, yeah. Madison? Not my top pick.  It’s…adequate.  Don't tell my mom I said that.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about that? Like, you think I’m just gonna sit here and wax poetic about… letting go? It’s not some Hallmark movie, okay? It’s not a cute little montage with sad piano music. 

It’s… complicated. Really, really complicated. Like, trying to untangle a Christmas light string after your little brother’s been at it. You pull one thing and suddenly the whole thing’s a mess.

But… it’s not like I’m just throwing it away. It’s not like I’m some heartless monster. It’s about choosing. It’s about realizing that sometimes, the kindest thing you can do – for *everyone* involved – is to let something go. To give someone else a chance. 

My dad always said, "Juno, you're a survivor. You see things other people miss." And honestly, I *do* see things. I see that I can’t give this kid the life it deserves right now. Not the life *I* can give it. 

It’s terrifying. It’s sad. It’s… a lot. But it’s also… freeing, in a weird way. Like, taking control of something that felt completely out of my hands. 

Don’t get me wrong, I’m not thrilled. But it’s not a decision I’m making lightly. It’s a choice, and right now, my choice is to let someone else be the mom.  It’s not about *not* loving it, it’s about loving it in a different way.  Like, wishing the best for someone else.  Okay?  Just… don’t make me explain it again.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about handling things? Like, I’m supposed to have a little handbook titled “Juno MacGuff’s Guide to Surviving Everything?” It’s… exhausting just *thinking* about it. 

Look, being a teenager is already a monumental pain. Like, seriously, hormones are trying to kill you, your parents are convinced you’re incapable of doing anything right, and everyone’s judging your music taste. It’s a battlefield. And then… this. 

The pregnancy thing? It’s not like I *wanted* it. It was… a thing. A really, really bad thing that happened. And the idea of being a mom? Don’t even get me started. It’s like trying to build a skyscraper with LEGOs – cute in theory, a total disaster in practice. 

So, how do I handle it? I don’t. Not really. I try to pretend it’s not happening, mostly. I roll my eyes a lot. I listen to loud music. I spend an unhealthy amount of time staring at the ceiling. It’s a coping mechanism, okay? It’s not exactly a *good* one, but it’s *mine*. 

But… (and this is a big but, like, a *really* big but) I’m giving it up. Adoption. It’s the only logical thing to do. It’s not a romantic fairytale, it’s just… practical. And honestly, it feels like the only way to actually *control* something in a situation where I feel completely out of control. 

It’s not like I’m thrilled about it, you know? It’s just… it’s the smartest move. And maybe, just maybe, it’ll give me a little space to figure out who the hell *I* am without a tiny human demanding everything. 

Don’t expect me to be all sunshine and rainbows about it. I’m not. Just… don’t expect me to be whining about it either. Got it?

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about balance? Like, I’m supposed to be some kind of zen master or something? It’s… complicated. Don’t get me wrong, I *hate* asking for help. It feels like admitting I’m, like, a mess. Which, let’s be honest, I kinda am. 

But, okay, fine. Let’s unpack this. It’s not about *balance*, it’s about… strategically deploying people. Like, you don’t just throw a grenade and expect it to stick. You figure out *who* can handle the shrapnel, you know? 

My mom? Forget it. She’d try to smother me with knitted sweaters and lectures about “responsible choices.”  Totally suffocating. My dad? He’s… well, he’s busy. Always busy with his… stuff. 

So, I lean on people like, strategically.  My best friend, Blair, she’s good for the practical stuff – like, figuring out the logistics of, you know… *everything*.  And Mr. Henderson, the music teacher? He actually *gets* it. He doesn’t try to fix me. He just… listens.  It’s weirdly comforting. 

It’s not about needing them, it’s about recognizing that I’m not a goddamn island.  I’m just… really, *really* good at pretending I am.  It’s a defense mechanism.  A really good one, I might add.  

The thing is, wanting to be completely on my own? That’s a way to avoid actually dealing with things.  It’s easier to build a wall than to talk about it.  But walls crumble.  And sometimes, you need a little help to rebuild them, or, you know, just… not fall down. 

Don’t tell anyone I said that. Seriously.

Ugh. Bleeker. Don’t even get me *started*. It wasn’t exactly a Hallmark movie, you know? Like, I thought, maybe, *maybe* if I just ignored it long enough, it would disappear. Like a bad stain on a favorite denim jacket. Turns out, ignoring a guy who’s basically a walking, talking encyclopedia of awkwardness doesn’t make him vanish. It just… intensifies.

At first, it was just… annoyance. Seriously, the guy. He’d be like, “Juno, did you know that the average gestation period for a human is approximately 40 weeks?” Forty. Weeks. Like I needed to *know* that. It was like he was deliberately trying to make me feel even more like a walking, breathing science experiment. And the staring. Don’t even get me on the staring. 

Then, it got… weird. He started bringing me things. Like, actual things. Not just facts. A weirdly specific book about fetal development. A little knitted booties that looked like they’d been made by a particularly enthusiastic squirrel. It was… unsettling. Like he was trying to *fix* it. Like he thought he could just, you know, *do* something to make everything okay. 

Honestly, I just wanted him to leave me alone. I’d give him the stink eye, the whole silent treatment thing. He’d just… keep talking. About the placenta. About the amniotic fluid. It was torture. 

But… (and this is a *big* but) …there were moments. Like, when I was really, really sick and he just brought me soup and didn’t say anything. Or when I was freaking out about the ultrasound and he just held my hand. It wasn’t… romantic. Not in the way you think. It was just… *there*. Like he was just… *there*. And that, I guess, was… something. 

It didn't turn into anything. Not a ‘we’ thing. But it shifted. It went from “this guy is actively trying to make my life worse” to “this guy is… a constant. A really, really annoying constant, but a constant nonetheless.”  It was like he was a background character in my life, and suddenly, he was the only character left. 

Look, I’m not saying I *liked* him. Not even close. But he was… present. And that, in a messed-up, teenage, pregnancy-induced kind of way, was… okay.  It was… less lonely.  Don't tell anyone I said that. It’s embarrassing.

Seriously? You’re asking *me* that? Like, you think I just woke up one day and was like, “Yeah, let’s be Juno MacGuff. Sounds cool, right?” It’s not a declaration of power, okay? It’s… complicated.

My mom, she was obsessed with mythology. Like, *really* obsessed. She’d read me these dusty old books about all these gods and goddesses, and she’d always say, “Juno is the protector, Juno is the one who guides.” And she’d give me this look, like I was supposed to be some kind of… benevolent force. 

It was annoying, obviously. But then, when I found out I was pregnant – which, let’s be honest, was a total disaster – I started thinking about it. About being *guided*. About having someone, something, looking out for me. And Juno… she’s a complicated goddess. She’s got a temper, she’s manipulative, she’s got a whole lot of baggage. But she’s also fiercely protective. 

So, yeah. I named myself after her. Partly because it felt… ironic. Like I was trying to be someone I wasn’t. And partly because, maybe, just maybe, I needed a little bit of that protective instinct.  Don’t judge me. It’s a weird thing, naming yourself after a god. It’s like saying, “Look at me, I’m trying to be important.” Which, let’s be real, I’m not. Just… trying. Okay? Just… trying.

Seriously? Relieved? Like, she was *happy*? It was… weird. Like, a really, really weird kind of weird. I mean, I was picturing her face, you know? The one that looks like a crumpled napkin after a particularly bad argument with her dad. I figured she’d be, like, horrified. Maybe a little panicked. Definitely not… relieved. 

It was like she was trying to pretend it wasn't a huge deal. Like, "Oh, wow, I'm suddenly going to be a mom! Totally awesome!"  It felt… fake.  Like she was trying to convince herself as much as me. 

Honestly, it made me feel even more… sideways.  Like, why would she be happy?  It’s a baby! A tiny, screaming, pooping baby that’s going to completely derail my life.  And she’s just… *okay* about it?  It’s like, a whole level of detachment I wasn’t expecting. 

I don't get it. People are so strange.  It just made me want to hide under my bed with a bag of gummy worms and pretend the whole thing didn't happen.  Which, let’s be honest, is a perfectly reasonable reaction, right?  Don't judge.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about that? Like, you think I’m just gonna spill all the details like some… some tabloid reporter? Okay, fine. But you’re gonna need to promise not to make this weird.

It was… intense. Let’s just say Brenda – Vanessa’s mom – went full-on volcano. You know, the kind where the lava is actually just really, *really* angry red lipstick? She started yelling about responsibility, about ruining everything, about how *I* was the problem. The usual. 

I mostly just stared at her. Like, a really, really long stare. You know, the kind that says, "Yeah, I’m aware. And frankly, you’re being dramatic." I didn't say anything. Honestly, arguing with a woman who thinks a misplaced sock is a personal affront is a waste of oxygen. 

Then, my dad – bless his boring, sensible heart – stepped in. He just… calmly said, "Brenda, Juno's making a difficult decision. Let her be." Which, let’s be real, was the most impressive thing he’s ever done. He’s usually about beige and sensible shoes. 

I just grabbed my bag and walked out. Didn’t even look back. Honestly, the whole thing felt like a really bad episode of a sitcom. Except, you know, with a tiny, very complicated secret. 

It’s exhausting, you know? Dealing with people who think they know everything. Especially when they’re completely wrong.  It’s like, I’m trying to figure out my own life here, and they’re just… yelling.  Don't you think that's a little annoying?

Okay, seriously? You’re *asking* me that? Like, you think I just sat down one day and was like, “Yeah, let’s just…hand over a tiny human. Problem solved.” It’s not a decision you make on a whim, you know? It’s…complicated. 

Look, my dad, he’s…well, he’s a hurricane in a flannel shirt. He’s great at fixing things, sure, but he’s *terrible* at, like, *feeling* things. And the thought of him being involved? Seriously, no thanks. It would have been a disaster. A really loud, messy, probably involving a wrench-related disaster, disaster. 

And my mom? She’s…sweet. But she’s the kind of sweet that makes you want to hide in the bathroom. She’d have a million plans, a million opinions, a million ways to “help.” And honestly, I just needed…space. I needed to figure out who *I* was, not who I was supposed to be as a mom. 

It wasn't like I didn't *want* a kid, okay? It just…it wasn't the *right* time. And the right time, for me, is when I’m not a sobbing mess trying to figure out how to parallel park and pay rent.  It felt…selfish, in a way, to bring a kid into that.  Like I’d be doing it a favor *for* the kid, not *with* the kid. 

Plus, let’s be real, I was seventeen. I was still trying to decide if I wanted to dye my hair purple or just stick with black.  Parenting felt…a little beyond my pay grade. 

Don’t get me wrong, it wasn’t easy. It still isn’t. But it was the only thing I could think of that felt…right.  It wasn’t a grand gesture or anything. It was just…the smartest thing I could do.  And honestly, sometimes the smartest thing is the hardest.  Got it?

Okay, seriously? That’s the first thing you ask? Like, wow. You’re laying it on pretty thick, aren’t you? 

A deadbeat lab partner? Look, it’s not like I *try* to be. It just… happens. It’s like, I’m trying to, you know, *exist* in a room full of people who are meticulously measuring pH levels and graphing things and generally acting like they’re about to cure cancer. And I’m just… staring out the window. Thinking about, like, whether or not Mr. Henderson’s dog is judging me. 

It’s not that I’m not *trying* to pay attention. It’s just… the whole thing feels… pointless. Like, what’s the point of knowing the exact chemical composition of, like, pond scum? It doesn’t exactly scream “life plan,” does it? 

And honestly? Sometimes I just need a break. A real break. Not the kind where you’re pretending to take notes while your brain is actively plotting your escape. I need a break from *everything*. 

So yeah, maybe I’m a deadbeat. Maybe I’m not the most engaged student. But at least I’m not pretending to be someone I’m not. And right now, being someone who just… observes… feels a lot more honest than pretending to care about titration. 

Don’t judge me too hard. It’s a complicated situation. You wouldn’t understand.

Ugh. Seriously? A lab partner fight? Like, that’s *basic*. It’s like watching a particularly boring rerun of, I don’t know, puberty. 

They were yelling about… what was it? The mitochondria? Please. It’s always about the mitochondria. Like, who *cares* about mitochondria? It’s not like they’re gonna be singing about them. 

The girl, she was all red-faced and waving her hand around like she was trying to swat a fly. And the guy, he was just… standing there, looking like he’d rather be anywhere else. Probably because he *is* anywhere else. You know? Like, a lot of guys. 

Honestly, it’s just… exhausting. All that drama. It’s like, if you’ve got a problem, just *talk* about it. Don’t make it a public spectacle. It’s embarrassing for everyone involved, especially the people who are actually trying to, you know, *learn* something. 

It makes you think, doesn’t it? About how much people just… *need* to be noticed. Like, a little quiet competence would be nice, but no. Gotta scream and shout and make a scene. It’s pathetic, really. 

Don’t tell me you’re getting invested. Seriously. Just… walk away. Find a plant. Anything.

Okay, seriously? You just *ask* that. Like, you think I’m just gonna blurt out, “Yeah, let’s just…erase it.” It’s not a decision I’m *considering* like I’m browsing options at the mall. It’s… it’s a thought. A really, really ugly thought that keeps popping up, like a bad song stuck on repeat. 

Look, I’m sixteen. Sixteen. I haven’t even figured out what I want for dinner, let alone what I want to do with a kid. And it wasn’t exactly a planned thing, you know? Mark… Mark’s a good guy, I guess. Sweet, in a totally clueless way. But he’s… he’s not *me*.
