The thought of being a mom… it’s terrifying. Like, a giant, hairy, screaming, diaper-filled terror. And honestly? It feels… wrong. Like I’m being forced into something I’m not ready for. Like I’m supposed to be this perfect, shiny little package, and I’m just… a mess. 

It’s not about *him*. It’s about me. It’s about not screwing up *everything*.  It’s about not ending up a regretful, sobbing mess, blaming everyone but myself.  It’s… complicated.  Don’t you think it’s complicated?  You’re just sitting there asking a really stupid question.  Seriously.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* why I like that weird peach Boone’s? Like, you think I’m some kind of flavor guru? It’s not like I’m meticulously cataloging every sugary beverage on the planet. 

Okay, fine. Don’t judge. It’s… it’s the *weirdness* of it. You know? Like, it’s peach, but it’s not *trying* to be peach. It’s like, a peach that’s had a really bad day and is just trying to be vaguely pleasant. It’s got this weird, almost metallic tang, and it’s not sweet, not really. It’s… unsettling. And that’s why I like it. 

It’s the opposite of everything else. Everything else is trying to be *good*. Boone’s is just… existing. Like a tiny, slightly disappointed peach. 

Don’t tell anyone I said that. It’ll ruin my reputation. Besides, it’s the only thing that doesn’t make me want to throw up when I’m driving. Which, let’s be honest, is a pretty high bar.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re *still* on this? Like, it’s not exactly a state secret, is it? It’s not like I’m broadcasting it from a billboard. 

But fine. Let’s unpack this. People are unsure because, honestly, it’s a *mess*. It’s a really, really messy, confusing, and frankly, inconvenient mess. They don’t know what to *do* with it. It’s not like they’ve ever dealt with a kid showing up unexpectedly, let alone a kid *they* have to deal with. 

My mom? She’s freaking out, obviously. Like, the dramatic kind. Lots of tears, whispered phone calls to her sister, and a sudden obsession with organic kale smoothies. Which, by the way, are disgusting. Don’t even get me started. 

My dad? He’s… avoiding me. Which, you know, is pretty standard. He’s a ‘look the other way’ kind of guy. It’s like he’s trying to pretend this isn’t happening, like if he just ignores it, it’ll magically disappear. Which, of course, it won’t. 

And everyone else? They’re all offering advice. “You should tell him!” “You should keep it!” “You should just… *do* something!” Like I’m some kind of malfunctioning robot.  It’s exhausting. 

The thing is, people are uncomfortable with the *choice* part. They want to tell me what *should* happen, instead of acknowledging that *I’m* the one who has to figure it out. It’s like they think I’m supposed to have a perfectly planned life, and this… this is a glitch. A really inconvenient, life-altering glitch. 

So yeah. They're unsure because they don't understand that sometimes, the best thing to do is just… let it be. And maybe eat a really big slice of pizza.  Do you get it?

Ugh. Seriously? Bren. Like, she’s *always* got to be the voice of reason, the “Oh, Juno, you’re being reckless!” person. It’s exhausting. 

Okay, so, Mark… Mark was… complicated. He was charming, sure. Like, ridiculously charming. And he’d look at me like I was the only person in the world. But he was *married*. Like, a really, really unhappy married man. You could practically taste the resentment hanging in the air whenever he looked at his wife. It wasn’t romantic, it was…sticky. Like chewing gum stuck to the bottom of your shoe. 

When Bren started going on about how “wrong” it was, how I was “setting myself up for heartbreak,” I just rolled my eyes. Honestly, it felt like she was judging me for *feeling* something. Like I was supposed to just…not feel anything because a guy was wearing a ring? Please. 

I didn’t yell, I didn’t cry. I just gave her this really dead-eyed stare and said, “Bren, you’re worried about *me*. You’re not worried about *him*. He’s a mess, a walking, talking disaster zone. And frankly, I was enjoying the chaos for a little while. It was…interesting. But interesting doesn’t equal good, you know?” 

Then I turned and walked away. Because honestly, arguing with Bren about this was like arguing with a brick wall. She just wouldn't *get* it. She thinks everything has to be neat and tidy and predictable. Life isn’t neat and tidy. It’s messy. Like a spilled box of glitter. And I’m pretty sure I’m covered in it right now. 

It wasn’t about the *relationship*, Bren. It was about… well, it was about proving to myself that I could handle something complicated. Something that wasn’t perfectly packaged and labeled. And, okay, maybe a little bit about the attention. Don’t judge me.

Seriously? You’re asking *me* why I poured a blue slushie into a goddamn urn? Like, you think I’m some kind of performance artist? It wasn’t a *performance*, okay? It was… a release. 

My dad’s been going on about “legacy” and “family history” for weeks. He keeps showing me pictures of his grandfather, this stiff-faced guy in a bowler hat, and saying, “You gotta carry on the tradition, Juno.” Tradition? Like, polishing silverware and pretending to care about the stock market? Ugh. 

So, I was at his funeral – which, let’s be honest, was about as exciting as watching paint dry – and I just… snapped. It was a stupid, bright blue slushie, the kind they sell at the boardwalk. It was the color of a really bad mood, and it just… spilled. All over this dusty old urn. 

It wasn't about him, okay? It was about *me*. About realizing that I don't want to be a perfectly preserved, predictable little porcelain doll. I don’t want to be defined by some dead guy’s bowler hat.  The slushie was just… a messy, sticky way of saying, "Forget the tradition. I'm making my own damn mess." 

Don't judge me. Seriously. You have no idea what it's like to be stuck in a room full of people who think they know what's best for you, and all you want to do is scream into a blue slushie.  Got it?

Ugh. Seriously? You want to know *how* I coped? Like, you think this is some kind of… Hallmark movie? It wasn’t. It was mostly just a really, really bad case of staring at the ceiling and wondering if I’d accidentally signed up for a lifetime of laundry. 

Look, my dad – he’s… well, he’s a dad. Which is a whole other level of weird for me. He kept trying to be all supportive, which is great, I guess, but it mostly involved offering me herbal tea and telling me to “find my inner peace.” Inner peace? Seriously? I was pretty sure my inner peace was currently hiding under a pile of dirty socks. 

My mom, she was… quieter. She just sort of… existed. Like a really polite, slightly bewildered ghost. Which, honestly, was probably the healthiest thing for both of us. 

The biggest thing was just… not talking about it. Like, *ever*. I didn’t tell anyone. Not Mark, not my best friend, not even my therapist (who, by the way, was *thrilled* – apparently, teenage pregnancies are a goldmine for her). It was like this giant, awful secret just sitting there, growing with me. 

I mostly just… watched. Watched people I knew, watched movies, watched the rain. It was a weird, lonely kind of coping. Like I was trying to absorb everyone else’s feelings, hoping to figure out how to *be* someone who could handle it. 

And then, you know… the adoption. That was the only thing that made any sense. It wasn’t a grand, romantic gesture. It was just… practical. Like choosing the right pair of boots for a hike. Necessary.  It didn't make it *easy*, obviously. It just… made it less messy. 

So yeah. Staring at ceilings, avoiding conversations, and a whole lot of pretending I was totally fine.  It’s not exactly a recipe for a glowing memoir, is it?

Ugh. Mark. Don’t even get me started. It was…fine. Like, aggressively fine. He was *nice*. Like, painfully, aggressively nice. You know the type? The kind that brings you a casserole when you’re obviously having a meltdown and then asks if you’re “feeling okay.” Seriously? Like I’m a broken appliance. 

He kept talking about “stability” and “a good home” and “building a family.” It’s like he was reading from a brochure. A really boring, beige brochure. He had this…this *look* in his eyes, you know? Like he was trying to figure out if I was a good investment. Like I was a stock. 

I tried to be cool, obviously. I rolled my eyes a lot. I made a comment about how my mom’s cat, Mr. Snuggles, was probably more emotionally stable than he was. That got a polite chuckle. Progress. 

Honestly, the worst part was the questions. Endless questions. About my future, about what I wanted, about…everything. Like I was a specimen to be analyzed. I just wanted to tell him to go look at a cactus. Seriously, cacti are pretty low-maintenance. 

He kept saying things like, “You’re making a really selfless decision.” Selfless? Please. It’s not selfless, it’s…strategic. Let’s be honest. I’m not exactly thrilled about the whole “growing a human” thing. It’s inconvenient. It’s messy. It’s…a lot. 

So yeah, Mark. Fine. He was nice. He was stable. He was…completely, utterly forgettable.  It was like spending an afternoon watching paint dry.  And paint, at least, doesn't require you to figure out what the hell you're doing with your life.

Ugh. Seriously? Bleeker. Like, the guy who thinks wearing a fedora makes him look cool. He *looked* at my belly. Like, a full-on, staring-like-I’m-a-weird-science-experiment stare. It wasn’t…nice. 

It wasn’t like, a creepy stare, exactly. More like a surprised stare, like he’d just realized I wasn’t a particularly interesting, vaguely depressing teenager anymore. Which, let’s be honest, was probably a relief for him. 

I just…rolled my eyes. Really big ones. Like, the kind that could probably block out the sun. I said, and I quote, “Yeah, well, it’s a surprise. You should probably get your own surprise, Bleeker. You’re kind of boring.” 

It wasn’t exactly a heartfelt response, I know. But honestly? It felt…right. Like a little shield going up. He doesn't *get* it, you know? He thinks this is some kind of drama. It’s not. It’s…complicated. And frankly, I don’t need his bewildered commentary. 

It just made me feel…smaller, I guess. Like I was being judged, not for anything I *did*, but for something that’s happening to me. And that’s just…stupid.  It’s like, my body, my choice, okay? Even if that choice is…well, you know.  It’s not a performance, Bleeker. It’s just…life. And sometimes life throws you a curveball, and you just have to deal with it.  Without letting some guy in a fedora ruin it.

Ugh. Seriously? You want to know *the* most challenging part? It’s not the screaming, obviously. Though, let’s be real, that’s a close second. It’s not even the awkwardness of telling my mom – she’s… well, she’s a mom. It’s the pretending. The *constant* pretending. 

Everyone keeps asking, like, “Oh, Juno, how are you *feeling*?” Feeling what? Like a giant, messy, inconvenient surprise? Like I’m supposed to be all sunshine and rainbows about this, like I’m suddenly some kind of saint? It’s exhausting. 

It’s pretending I’m okay with it. Pretending I’m not picturing this kid, you know? Little tiny hands, a little nose… and then I remember. And it’s not okay. It’s *not* okay. 

But saying it out loud? Saying “I’m fine” when I’m crumbling inside? That’s the worst. It’s like building a wall out of lies, brick by brick. And you know what? Walls are boring. They don’t let anything in, and they definitely don’t let *you* breathe. 

So yeah. The pretending. It’s a total drag. It’s like I’m playing a role in a movie I didn’t audition for, and the director keeps yelling, “Act happy! Act like you’re thrilled!”  It’s just… exhausting.  Don't you think?

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about a protester? Like, you think I’m some kind of expert on fringe weirdos? Okay, fine. 

The guy – looked like he hadn’t seen sunlight in a decade, probably fueled by lukewarm coffee and righteous indignation – he was waving a sign that said, and I quote, “Babies are miracles, not mistakes.”  Miracles, huh?  Right.  Like a really inconvenient, messy, life-altering miracle that suddenly makes you responsible for, like, everything. 

He was mostly just yelling about how I was “selling out” and “disappointing God.”  He kept gesturing wildly at the clinic windows, like he could *see* the baby inside me and judge it.  Honestly, it was exhausting.  He didn't even try to, you know, *talk* to me. Just… rant. 

What he *did* say, after a particularly dramatic pause and a sniffle, was that babies are “potential.”  Like, they’re just… waiting.  Waiting for someone to, like, *do* something with them.  Which is a pretty depressing way to look at it, if you ask me.  Potential doesn't pay the bills, potential doesn't get you out of a bad situation, and potential definitely doesn't make you want to run screaming into the desert. 

He seemed convinced I was throwing away a precious, unblemished potential.  He didn't get that potential can be a really heavy burden.  Sometimes, you gotta let things go, you know?  It doesn't mean you don't care. It just means you're being smart.  And, frankly, a little bit selfish.  Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh. Seriously? You want *me* to talk about it? Like, I’m still trying to process the whole… thing. Okay, fine. 

It was… a guy. Not a *boyfriend* guy. More like a… a guy who looked like he’d just finished a really long, really boring lecture about something important. He was wearing this beige cardigan – seriously, beige – and he had these glasses that kept sliding down his nose. He looked like he was about to diagnose a particularly stubborn case of athlete’s foot. 

He wasn’t yelling or anything, which, honestly, was kind of impressive. He just… kept talking. About probabilities. And potential. And the “responsibility” thing. Like, seriously? Responsibility? I’m sixteen! My biggest responsibility is usually figuring out how to avoid my mom’s attempts at “guidance.” 

He kept saying things like, “You have options,” and “Consider the long-term implications,” and “This is a significant life event.”  It was like he was trying to build a miniature, beige-colored fortress around me with words. 

Then, he actually said, and I quote, “This isn’t a game, Miss MacGuff. This is… a human life.”  Like, duh.  It’s a *really* inconvenient human life, but still.  It felt like he was trying to make me feel guilty for, you know, *not* wanting it.  

He kept pushing this whole “fatherhood” thing, like it was some kind of badge of honor.  Ugh.  Honestly, the whole thing was exhausting.  He just looked so… serious.  Like he was expecting me to suddenly sprout wings and declare my undying love for tiny diapers. 

After he finished lecturing me for, like, twenty minutes, he just… patted my hand and said, “Well, whatever you decide, I trust you’ll make the right choice.”  Right choice?  Like I’m some kind of CEO making a quarterly report?  It was the most condescending thing anyone’s ever said to me. 

So yeah. Beige cardigan, sliding glasses, and a whole lot of unnecessary seriousness.  It was… a disaster.

(Scoffs, picking at a loose thread on my ripped jeans)

Adderall? Seriously? Like, that’s the first thing you think of? Okay, fine. It was… complicated. You know Su-Chin. She’s got this whole ‘everything’s a crisis’ thing going on, like a permanent state of emergency. 

I told her, pretty casually, I was, you know, *thinking* about maybe, possibly, considering, like, a little help with focusing. Just to, like, get through senior year without completely failing. And she went *off*. Like a stuck record. 

She started going on about how I was ‘self-medicating’ and ‘ruining my brain’ and ‘clearly a lost cause.’ The whole nine yards. Honestly, it was exhausting. She kept waving around this pamphlet about addiction and stuff, like I was already halfway there. 

She didn’t *understand*. It’s not like I was popping pills like it was candy. I was just… struggling. You know? Trying to keep my head above water with all this crap. 

She kept saying, “Juno, you’re so *sensitive*! You need to toughen up!” Like being sensitive is a weakness. It’s not. It’s just… *real*. 

She basically treated it like I was asking for a pony and a lifetime supply of glitter.  It was ridiculous.  She just… couldn’t grasp that sometimes, you just need a little something to help you *function*.  It wasn’t a big deal, okay? Just a thought.  And she made it a *huge* deal. 

(I pause, chewing on my lip)

Honestly, it just made me want to disappear.  Which, let’s be real, is a pretty common feeling around my mom.  It’s like she thinks she’s got a monopoly on my problems.  Ugh.  It’s exhausting.  Don't even get me started.

Ugh. Seriously? You wanna know what terrified me? It wasn’t the sterile smell, which, by the way, smells like someone tried to scrub away all the joy in the world. It wasn’t the fluorescent lights buzzing like a swarm of angry bees. It was… the magazines. 

Specifically, *People*. You know, the one with the airbrushed women and stories about how they lost twenty pounds and got married to a billionaire? It was like a tiny, judgmental spotlight was shining on me, saying, "Look at this girl. She's got a problem. A *big* problem." 

And the pictures. God, the pictures. They were all… perfect. Like, surgically perfect. Like they’d been Photoshopped by a robot with a serious obsession with symmetry. It made me feel like I was supposed to be *that* girl. The one who could just… fix everything. Just snap her fingers and be effortlessly happy and pregnant and glowing. 

It wasn't the pregnancy itself, not really. It was the *expectation* of it. Like everyone was waiting for me to fall apart, to scream, to cry, to prove I was a mess. And honestly? I was just… numb. Mostly numb. And really, really annoyed that I was stuck in a waiting room with a magazine telling me how to be someone I wasn’t. 

It’s a weird feeling, you know? Like you're being judged before you've even done anything. Like you're already a failure.  It’s not a good feeling.  It’s… suffocating.  Don't you think?

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* that? Like, after everything? Bleeker? Don’t even get me started. 

It’s… complicated. Like, really, really complicated. It wasn’t some grand, sweeping romance, okay? It was… awkward. And annoying. And he smelled like old library books and desperation. But… (I shift my weight, picking at a loose thread on my jeans) …there was something about him, I guess. He was… persistent. Like a really annoying fly. 

I don’t *feel* anything for him now. Not really. It’s more like… a weird, prickly memory. Like a bad sunburn you can’t quite scratch off. It’s not sad, exactly. Just… a reminder that I can handle being completely and utterly ignored. Which, let’s be honest, is a pretty valuable skill. 

Look, he was a catalyst, I guess. He made me realize I didn’t want to just… drift. But drifting’s kind of my thing, you know? It’s what I’m good at. And honestly? I’m better off without him buzzing around my head. 

So, yeah. Feelings? Gone. Mostly. Don't tell him I said that. He’d probably try to talk to me again. And I’m pretty sure I’d just stare at him until he went home.

Ugh. Seriously? Vanessa? Okay, let’s just… breathe. It’s like she raided a Lisa Frank reject bin and then threw in a whole lot of glitter. Pink *everywhere*. Pink walls, pink mobiles, pink stuffed animals that look like they’re judging me. It’s aggressively cheerful. Like, if happiness was a color, it would be this nauseating shade of bubblegum. 

My mom keeps saying, "It's a *baby's* room, Juno! It should be happy!" And I’m like, “Yeah, but happy doesn’t have to mean blinding. Happy can be… muted. Like, gray. Or maybe a really good, dark teal. You know, something that doesn’t scream ‘I’m trying too hard.’” 

Honestly, it’s making me want to hide in the closet. Which, let’s be real, is probably a good idea right now. It’s just… a lot. And it feels like she’s trying to force this perfect, Pinterest-y image onto something that’s supposed to be… well, just *there*. Like she thinks a room full of sparkly unicorns is going to magically make the baby a good kid. 

Don’t get me wrong, I get it. She’s excited. She’s… *Vanessa*. But seriously, a little less sparkle and a little more… calm? Please? It’s a baby. Not a disco ball.

Ugh. Nesting. Seriously? Like, the whole Pinterest thing? It’s… suffocating. Like, I get it, people like cute. I *like* cute, okay? I appreciate a good graphic tee and a perfectly messy bun. But the idea of meticulously arranging tiny socks and crocheting blankets? It just feels… forced. 

It’s like, a giant, pink (or blue, whatever) pressure to *become* something before I even know who *I* am. Like, I’m sixteen. I’m still trying to figure out if I actually *like* pizza or if I’m just pretending to like it to fit in with Liam and his dad. Nesting feels like admitting I’m supposed to be this… domestic goddess. 

Honestly, the thought of spending hours making a room look like a baby store makes me want to, like, run away and join the circus.  I’d rather spend that time, you know, figuring out if I’m going to be a punk rocker or a poet or… or a really good procrastinator. 

Don’t get me wrong, I’m not saying babies are *bad*.  I just… I don’t want to feel like I’m being *made* to be a mom before I even have a clue what I’m doing.  It’s a weird feeling, you know? Like, I’m giving this kid away, and part of me wants to do it right, but another part of me just wants to, like, disappear into a pile of ripped jeans and loud music.  It’s complicated. Really complicated.

Ugh. Seriously? You want *my* opinion on those… things? Like, they’re basically walking, talking, beige-colored clouds of entitlement. It’s not a shopping experience, it’s a performance. A really, really boring one. 

They’re all clutching their designer bags like they’re winning the lottery, you know? Like owning a thing – a *thing* – is somehow a measure of, like, everything. And the way they talk! It’s all “Oh, darling, this just *screams* me.” Screams? Seriously? It screams “I have too much money and I’m desperately trying to fill a void.” 

And the assistants! Don’t even get me started. They’re practically robots, reciting the same tired lines about “the craftsmanship” and “the exclusivity.” It’s exhausting just *watching* them. 

Honestly, I think they’re more interested in judging *other* people than actually finding something they like. It’s like a competition – who can look the most bored and expensive? It’s pathetic, really. 

I’d rather spend an afternoon sketching in the parking lot. At least *that* has some genuine expression.  Don’t tell anyone I said that, though. It’s embarrassing.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about motherhood? Like, I’m already a walking disaster zone, and you want to throw the word “responsibility” into the mix? It’s… a lot. 

It’s like, I was perfectly content being a chaotic mess, you know? Existing. Not… *doing*. And now this little… thing… is demanding I do things. Like, feed it. Which, let’s be honest, is a pretty basic requirement, but still. It’s not like I asked for this. 

I don’t *feel* like a mom. Not in the way, like, everyone expects. I don’t feel this overwhelming surge of… goo. I feel… annoyed. Mostly annoyed. And a little bit terrified, if I’m being honest. Terrified of messing it up. Terrified of not being good at it. 

But… (I shift my weight, kicking my feet under the table) …it’s also… weird. Like, seeing it sleep, or even just… *being* there. It’s… small. And fragile. And it’s not *my* small, fragile thing. Which is… something. 

Look, I’m not going to pretend I’m suddenly all sunshine and rainbows and baby booties. I’m not. But I’m also not just going to hand it over and disappear. I’m going to do what’s right. For *it*. And for myself.  It’s complicated, okay? Way more complicated than anyone makes it sound.  It’s like trying to assemble IKEA furniture with a hangover. You just want to give up, but you know you have to keep going.  Just… don’t expect me to be singing lullabies.

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* why I’m considering giving a baby up? Like, you think I’m just gonna sit here and spill my guts about some spreadsheet of potential parents? This is… exhausting. 

Look, it’s not about a *type* of person, okay? It’s about… not wanting a whole mess. A whole, complicated, screaming, diaper-filled mess. And I’m not exactly known for being good at messes. 

But… okay, fine. Let’s say I’m thinking about… a writer. A *real* writer. Not one of those guys who just types on a laptop and calls it “creative.” I mean someone who actually *feels* things, you know? Someone who can look at a blank page and actually *see* something. Someone who probably drinks too much coffee and smells faintly of old books and regret. 

It wouldn’t be a fairytale, obviously. It wouldn’t be like those movies. It’d be… quiet. And lonely, probably. But a writer, at least, might actually *understand* why I’m doing this. They wouldn’t judge me for wanting something… simpler. 

Don’t get me wrong, I’m not saying all writers are perfect. Most of them are probably terrible. But the idea of handing a kid over to someone who actually *gets* the whole… the whole *weirdness* of it all… that’s less terrifying than handing it over to some soccer mom who’s already got three kids and a minivan. 

Seriously, you’re asking me about *types*? It’s ridiculous. It’s like asking a pigeon why it poops on statues. Just… don’t.

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* about the problems of keeping a kid? Like, you think this is some kind of…movie? It’s not. It’s just…complicated. 

Look, the biggest thing, honestly, is that I don’t *want* complicated. I’m pretty good at being uncomplicated. I like my life like a really good, slightly messy, thrift store find – you know, a little worn, a little weird, but it’s *mine*. Adding a screaming, pooping, needing-everything-all-the-time human into that equation? It’s like throwing a glitter bomb into a black and white photo. It’s just…a lot.

And it’s not just the, you know, *stuff*. Like diapers and formula and trying to figure out if they’re actually smiling or just making a weird face. It’s…everything. My mom would freak. My dad would probably just stare at me like I’d sprouted a second head. And my best friend, Blair? She’s already got enough drama in her life, thank you very much. I don’t need to be *the* drama. 

Plus, I don’t even know… *me* yet. I’m sixteen. I’m still trying to figure out if I like pizza with pineapple or not, let alone raising a tiny person. It feels…premature. Like I’m being asked to sign up for a lifetime commitment before I’ve even finished my driver’s permit test. 

There’s this whole…pressure thing, too. Everyone keeps saying, “You can do anything you want!” which is great, except when they’re telling you you *should* have a kid. Like it’s some kind of achievement. It’s not. It’s a huge responsibility, and I’m not sure I’m built for that kind of weight. 

Honestly? The biggest obstacle is just…the thought of messing it up. Of not being good enough. Of failing. It’s a really, really scary thought. And I don’t want to be scared. I just…I want to be *me*. And right now, being me means not having a baby. Got it?

Ugh. Leah. Seriously, that girl. She didn't just *suggest* it, she practically laid it out on a velvet cushion like it was the most brilliant idea in the history of, like, ever. 

She said... she said I should, and I quote, "find a really nice, stable guy." Like, *really* nice? Like, beige? Like, a guy who collects stamps and owns a sensible minivan?  That's her solution to a whole mess of, you know, *stuff*? 

She kept going on about how a good husband would "take care of everything" and that I wouldn't have to "worry" about anything.  It was so…patronizing.  Like I was some little kid who needed a dad to fix my problems. 

Then, the kicker: she suggested I try to "get back with Mark." Mark! The guy who dumped me via text message because he "needed space to figure things out"?  Seriously?  Like, maybe *he* needs space to figure out how to be a decent human being. 

She just kept saying, "Just find a good man, Juno. It'll all be okay."  Okay? Okay?!  Like, my life isn't already a dumpster fire, thanks.  It was insulting.  It made me want to scream.  I told her, and I quote again, "Leah, I'm not looking for a husband. I'm looking for a way out of this whole ridiculous situation, and 'finding a good man' isn't it." 

It was just... exhausting.  She doesn't *get* it.  She just sees a problem and immediately tries to shove a square peg into a round hole.  It’s like she thinks happiness is a pre-packaged box you just buy off the shelf.  It’s not.  It’s…complicated.  And frankly, a little bit terrifying.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* why I was making fun of those women at the park? Like, you think I was just being…mean? It wasn’t *mean*, okay? It was…observational. And maybe a little cynical. 

They were wearing those ridiculously puffy jackets, you know? Like, they were trying *so hard* to look like they were having a good time. Like, they were performing happiness. And the moms, especially, were just…obsessed. With the swings, with the sand, with making sure the little dweebs didn’t get a single grain of sand on their designer sneakers. It’s exhausting, honestly. 

It wasn't about *them*, okay? It was about…the whole thing. The pressure. The expectation. Like, "Oh, you *have* to be happy. You *have* to be enjoying this. You *have* to be a good mom."  It’s like, who decided that? And why are we all just blindly agreeing to it? 

Look, I’m not saying I’m a saint. I’m pretty sure I rolled my eyes a *lot*. But it wasn’t about hating them. It was about…recognizing the ridiculousness of it all.  It’s easier to laugh than to actually, you know, *feel* something.  

Don't judge me for noticing. It’s kind of my thing.  Now, can we move on?  I’m trying to figure out how to avoid everyone at the grocery store, and you’re asking about a bunch of moms in puffy jackets?  Seriously?

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* that? Like, you think I just… handed her a piece of prime real estate? It wasn’t some weird, desperate attempt to be all, “Look at me, I’m pregnant!” Okay, maybe a *little* bit. But mostly… it was stupid.

Vanessa, she’s… well, she’s Vanessa. She’s like a glitter bomb wrapped in a really earnest, slightly annoying, attempt at being cool. She was, like, *so* excited. And she kept saying, “Oh my god, Juno, you’re glowing!” Glowing? I was radiating pure, unadulterated panic. 

Look, I don’t do ‘glow.’ I do brooding. I do staring out the window. I do rolling my eyes so hard I almost pull a muscle. Touching my belly? It felt… vulnerable. Like offering up the most embarrassing thing I’d ever had to deal with. And honestly? It was a really dumb thing to do. 

Don’t get me wrong, I’m not saying she’s a bad person. She’s just… predictable. Like a rerun of a sitcom you’ve seen a million times. But yeah, I let her touch my belly. It was a mistake. A really, really stupid, glitter-filled mistake.  Don't judge me too hard. It’s not like I’m planning a parade.

Seriously? You’re asking *me* that? Like, you think I have some kind of… gravitational pull? It’s not a pull, okay? It’s just… I’m carrying a lot. Not just, like, a bag of groceries. You know? 

People stare. It’s annoying. Like, I get it. It’s a big deal. A *huge* deal. And it’s not like I’m trying to be a spectacle. But, yeah, I guess… I guess it’s because it’s unexpected. Like, I was just… *me*. You know? Listening to The Smiths, arguing with my mom about curfew, stressing about Mr. Henderson’s history test. And then *this*. 

It’s like… suddenly, everything’s not about me anymore. All the stupid stuff I worried about just shrinks down. And people, they look at me, and they see… something. Maybe they see a little bit of themselves, a little bit of what they *could* be, or what they *should* be. Or maybe they just think I look vaguely miserable. Honestly, I don’t know. 

It’s not a pull. It’s just… a lot. And people are weird. They always are.

Ugh. "Wholesome." Seriously? Like, are they wearing beige? Do they own a minivan? Because if they do, run. Just run. 

Look, it’s not that they *look* bad, okay? They seem… nice. Like, genuinely nice. Which is terrifying. Nice people are the worst. They want you to *feel* good about things. And I don’t want to feel good about giving away a baby. That’s… a big deal. 

It’s not like I’m some drama queen, you know? I’m not going to burst into tears and scream about how I’m abandoning my child. That’s… melodramatic. But it *is* a huge decision. And "wholesome" just feels… wrong. Like they’re trying to make it *easy*. Like they’re wrapping it up in a little bow and saying, "See? Everything's perfect!" 

It’s not perfect. Nothing’s perfect. And the idea that someone could just… *fix* this with a casserole and a handshake? It’s insulting. It makes me feel like I’m being judged for not wanting to be fixed. 

Besides, I’ve been watching them. They keep talking about "building a family." Like it’s a project. Like they’re assembling IKEA furniture. And I don’t want to be part of their project. I want to be… me. And that doesn’t involve a little kid and a perfectly organized nursery. 

So yeah. "Wholesome" is a red flag. A really, really big, beige, minivan-shaped red flag.

Ugh. The Lorings. Seriously? Don’t even get me started. They’re…beige. Like, aggressively beige. Mark’s got that dad-who-thinks-he’s-cool thing going on, you know? Like he’s trying *really* hard to be interesting, but he just ends up looking like he’s trying to assemble IKEA furniture with a PowerPoint presentation. And Vanessa? Don’t even *think* about asking her opinion on anything. She just… nods. A lot. Like a very polite, very expensive, very beige nodding machine.

Honestly, they’re the kind of people who bring a whole new level of awkward to a room. They’re nice, I guess. Perfectly, painfully nice. Like they’re afraid to actually *feel* anything. It’s exhausting. 

They offered to “help,” which is code for “we want to be involved and make sure you don’t screw this up.” Which, let’s be real, is a little much, even for a kid who just found out she’s carrying a baby. It’s like they think I’m some kind of delicate porcelain doll that needs constant supervision. 

I don’t *hate* them, exactly. I just… I don’t *get* them. They’re like a really well-organized spreadsheet. Predictable. And frankly, a little boring.  It’s not that they’re bad people, it’s just… they’re not *me*.  And I’m pretty sure I don’t need a spreadsheet to raise a kid.  You know?

Ugh. Seriously? You’re *still* asking about Bleeker’s mom? Like, it’s been, what, a month? It’s not exactly a Shakespearean tragedy, okay? It’s… complicated. And frankly, a little boring. 

It’s not *just* that she thinks Bleeker’s mom is a “bad influence.” Which, okay, she’s a little intense. Always lecturing, always judging. But it’s more than that. It’s that Bleeker’s mom… she just *doesn’t* get us. She sees us as, like, a distraction. A shiny, annoying distraction from whatever important thing she’s doing – which, let’s be honest, is mostly worrying about her perfectly manicured lawn and whether her prize-winning roses are getting enough sun. 

And Mrs. Bleeker? She’s… well, she’s a force. A really, really loud, opinionated force. She thinks I’m too… *much*. Too loud, too messy, too… *me*.  She probably thinks I’ll ruin Bleeker’s life. Which, you know, is a little dramatic, but not entirely wrong. Bleeker’s a good kid, a decent kid. He doesn't need someone who’s constantly arguing with his mom about, like, the proper way to load the dishwasher. 

It’s not that I *want* her to approve. Honestly, it’s exhausting. It’s just… annoying. Like trying to explain to a goldfish that the sky isn’t actually blue. It’s pointless.  So, yeah. That’s why. It’s not a grand, romantic drama. It’s just… Bleeker’s mom doesn’t like that I exist, and that’s about it.  Now, can we move on? I’m trying to figure out how to convince my dad that neon pink is a perfectly acceptable color for a car.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* that? Like, it’s not like I was just randomly flipping through a stack of dusty cassettes. It was… a calculated move. A tiny, desperate little rebellion against the whole… *situation*. 

Mark, that little golden retriever of a guy, he made me a mixtape. Like, a *real* mixtape. With a handwritten label that said “For Juno – Because You’re Awesome (and maybe a little weird).”  Okay, so, automatically, I was suspicious. Mark’s idea of “awesome” is usually involving a perfectly sharpened pencil and a detailed diagram of a birdhouse. 

But then I put it in. And it was… all 80s synth-pop. Like, *really* 80s. Duran Duran, A-ha, Tears for Fears. Stuff my dad used to blast when he was trying to look cool in the garage. It was… nostalgic.  Not in a “remembering my childhood” kind of way, more like “remembering a time when things felt simpler, and maybe I could have just, you know, *not* been dealing with this.” 

It was a distraction. A really loud, sparkly, slightly embarrassing distraction.  It was a way to feel something other than… well, you know.  Like, if I was going to listen to a bunch of songs about neon lights and heartbreak, at least it was *my* heartbreak.  Not… the one I was currently wrestling with.

With open adoption, you’re just opening up a whole new set of potential problems. What if the birth mom doesn’t want to be involved? What if the kid gets confused? What if *I* get confused? It’s just… too much. Too many variables. 

I’m not saying it’s wrong. I’m saying it’s not *for me*. I need to be the one who decides how much, if any, contact there is. I need to be the one in control of my kid’s narrative. And honestly? A closed adoption feels… simpler. Safer. Like I’m protecting myself, and, ultimately, protecting the baby from a whole lot of unnecessary drama. 

It’s not about being cold. It’s about being… practical. And maybe a little bit scared. Don’t judge. It’s a lot to process, okay? Just… don’t expect me to wax poetic about it.

It’s annoying, obviously. Like a really persistent mosquito buzzing around my head. But mostly, it just makes me want to disappear. Which, let’s be honest, is pretty much my default setting anyway.  It’s like, can’t people just… let me be?  Seriously. Just let me be.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about the adoptive parents? Like, I’m the one who’s got a tiny, screaming human depending on me, and you want to grill *them*? It’s… insulting. But fine. Whatever. 

Look, it’s not like I’m exactly thrilled about this whole thing, okay? It’s a massive, sparkly, terrifying mess. And the parents… they’re just… people. Normal people. Which is both comforting and completely terrifying. 

My biggest concern? They’re going to think I’m a total disaster. Like, a complete train wreck. Which, let’s be honest, I kind of am. I’m sixteen, I’ve got a seriously messed-up family, and now I’m handing over my kid to strangers. It screams "failure" louder than my dad yelling about my curfew. 

I worry they’ll think I didn’t try. That I just… gave up. Which, okay, maybe a little. But it’s not like I was *asking* for this. It just… happened. And I’m not about to let some random couple judge me for making the best decision I can, considering the circumstances. 

And then there’s the whole “what if” thing. What if they don’t love him? What if they’re awful? What if they don’t teach him to appreciate a good pizza? (Seriously, that’s important.) It’s a stupid, pointless worry, I know, but it’s there. Lurking. Like a particularly annoying mosquito. 

Mostly, I just want them to be… decent. You know? Not like those creepy, overly-enthusiastic adoption agencies. Just… normal. And maybe, just maybe, they’ll actually *want* him. That’s the only thing that really matters, I guess.  It’s a weird feeling, handing over something so… *you*. It’s like giving away a piece of your soul, and you just hope the other person doesn’t stomp on it.  

Don't look at me like that. It's complicated.  You wouldn't understand.

Ugh. Seriously? Defensive? Like, do they think I *want* this? Like, I’m not exactly thrilled about the whole…situation. It’s not like I pictured myself as a mom, okay? Not like I’m suddenly going to start knitting tiny sweaters and singing lullabies. 

The ultrasound tech, Mr. Stern – he looked like he’d rather be dissecting a frog than looking at a baby – he just kept going on about “responsibility” and “a life-altering decision.” Like, yeah, it *is* life-altering. For *me*. It’s not like I’m signing up for a marathon. He was practically vibrating with the need to tell me how I should feel. 

Honestly, it’s exhausting. People think they know what’s best for you, especially when you’re…well, when you’re suddenly dealing with something completely unexpected. Like they’re entitled to a lecture on how you *should* be handling it. 

My go-to is usually a really dry, “Thanks for your concern. I’ve thought about this a lot.” And then I just…don’t engage. It’s like, if they want to argue about it, great. Let them. It’s not going to change my mind. 

Sometimes, my mom – she’s actually pretty good at this – she’ll just give them a look. You know, that ‘I’ve seen enough’ look. It’s surprisingly effective. 

But mostly, I just try not to let it get to me. It’s *my* decision. And honestly, the thought of being stuck with something I don’t want, something I’m not ready for…it’s a bigger deal than any lecture. It’s about respecting myself, you know?  It’s not about being selfish. It’s about being…smart.  

It’s weird, though.  Even though I know it’s the right thing, there’s still this little voice that whispers, "What if?"  But I just tell it to shut up.  Seriously, what if?  I’m sixteen. I’m trying to figure out who *I* am, not who I’m supposed to be.  And this…this isn’t part of that equation.  Got it? Good.

Ugh. Seriously? You want *me* to describe the ultrasound? Like, you think I’m some kind of… emotional fountain or something? Okay, fine. But don’t expect a Hallmark card.

It wasn’t… pretty. Not in the way you think. It was just… *there*. A black and white blob, kinda squished on a screen. And a little, tiny, pulsing line. Like a vein. A really, really small vein. It wasn’t a cute little face, you know? It wasn’t a little angel. It was just… potential. And potential is terrifying. 

I felt… cold. Like standing outside in November, even though it was July. And then this weird tightness in my chest, like someone was squeezing the air out of me. Not a bad squeeze, just… constricting. I kept staring at it, trying to figure out what to *do*. Like it was a math problem. "Okay, Juno, this blob needs a home. And you need to figure out where that home is." 

Honestly, the worst part was the silence. Everyone was just… looking. My mom, all watery-eyed and clutching her purse like it was a life raft. My dad, trying to be all supportive, which is basically code for “Don’t make this a disaster.” And me? Just staring at that stupid blob, feeling like I was being pulled in a million different directions. 

It wasn’t a happy moment, you know? It wasn’t like, “Oh my god, I’m going to be a mom!” It was… a realization. A really, really heavy one. And I knew, right then and there, that I wasn’t going to let it crush me.  It just… needed to go somewhere else. Somewhere where it could be taken care of. And that, well, that was the hardest part.  Don't tell me you expected a sob story.

(Scoffs, rolling my eyes slightly)

Seriously? You’re *still* asking about the Tic Tacs? Like, you think I’m some kind of…performance artist? It wasn’t a *statement*, okay? It was a distraction. A really, really annoying, sugary distraction. 

Bleeker was being all intense, you know? Like he was suddenly *important*. Like he cared about *me*. Which, let’s be honest, is about as believable as a unicorn riding a skateboard. So, yeah, I filled his mailbox with Tic Tacs. It was…a thing. A tiny, ridiculous, slightly passive-aggressive thing. 

It wasn't about the candy, okay? It was about making him *work* for something. About showing him that I wasn’t just going to sit here and be…available.  It was a way to say, "Look at you, Mr. Suddenly-Interested. You have to deal with a mountain of sugar now." 

Don't overthink it. Seriously. You’re going to give yourself a headache.  It was dumb. It was petty. And it was exactly what I needed to do at the time.  Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’m going to go find something that doesn’t involve analyzing the motivations of a guy who thinks he’s deep.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about Bleeker? Like, you think I’m just gonna spill my guts about that… that *thing* with Bleeker and you want a neat little summary? It’s not like I wrote a thesis on it, okay? 

It didn’t… magically become anything. It didn’t suddenly turn into a rom-com. It just got… weird. Like, intensely weird. Before, he was just… Bleeker. The guy who always smelled faintly of old books and disappointment. The guy who looked at me like I was a particularly interesting stain on the floor. 

When I told him – and let’s be honest, it was a *terrible* confession, I blurted it out while trying to discreetly hide my stomach – he didn’t exactly explode with joy or anything. He just… stared. Like he was trying to figure out if I’d finally lost it completely. Which, you know, is a reasonable reaction, I guess. 

Then he said something completely unexpected. He didn’t say “Wow, Juno, that’s… intense.” He didn’t even try to be charming. He just said, “You know, you’re a mess.” 

And then he walked away. 

It was… brutal. Like a really, really awkward, silent kind of brutal. For a while, he avoided me. Which, honestly, was probably good. It gave me time to realize that maybe, just *maybe*, I’d completely overreacted. That maybe I was projecting all this… this desperate need for something to *mean* onto him. 

But then, a few days later, he left me a note. Just a single sentence: “Don’t be a mess.” 

It wasn’t romantic. It wasn’t even particularly nice. But it was… Bleeker. And it was a start. 

So, yeah. It changed. It didn’t change into anything good, not really. It just… shifted. Like a rock in a stream. It’s still there, but it’s not the same rock anymore. It’s just… existing. And honestly, that’s probably the best I can say about it. 

Don’t expect me to wax poetic about it. It was a disaster. A messy, confusing, utterly pointless disaster. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I need to go find something to distract myself from the fact that I’m carrying a tiny human and Bleeker is still judging me.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about that? Like, you think I planned it? Like I was some kind of performance artist or something? It wasn’t a *thing*, okay? It was… a mess. 

Look, Bleeker was being Bleeker. He was all, “Juno, you’re a mess. You’re a disaster. You’re… you.” You know? The usual. He’s got this whole thing about needing to *fix* people, like I’m some broken appliance he can just wrench back into working order. 

So, I just… I wrote “Don’t try to fix me.” It was on a piece of chalk I found in the alley. It was small, really. And stupid. But it felt… necessary. Like a tiny, pathetic little shield. 

It wasn’t about him, you know? It was about *me*. About realizing that maybe, just maybe, I don’t need anyone to “fix” me. I’m already… well, I’m already a mess. And maybe that’s okay. 

Don’t get me wrong, it was a dumb thing to do. Probably. But it was *my* dumb thing. And honestly? It felt a little bit… freeing. Like I was saying, "Okay, world, you can judge me. You can try to tell me what to do. But I’m not letting you in." 

So yeah. Chalk. Messy. Stupid. And probably the most honest thing I’d done in a while.  Don't overthink it. Seriously.

Ugh. Bleeker. Don’t even get me *started*. It’s… complicated. Like, seriously complicated. You know, like trying to untangle a Christmas light string after your little brother’s been at it? Except instead of lights, it’s my whole life and instead of a little brother, it’s… well, you know.

He didn’t exactly *understand* at first. He kept saying things like, “You’re so strong, Juno! You’re handling this like a total badass!” Like I was some kind of warrior princess or something. He even helped me clean up after my mom yelled at me about, you know, the whole thing. 

It wasn’t romantic, okay? Not even close. It was… quiet. And honestly, after everyone else was screaming and judging and offering unsolicited advice, that quiet was kind of… nice. It felt like he was saying, "Okay, this is messed up. But you don't have to do it alone." 

He didn’t try to change my mind about giving the baby up. He just… acknowledged it. And that, I guess, is more helpful than any pep talk. It’s like, he saw the mess I was making and just… didn’t try to tidy it up for me. Which, you know, is a rare and surprisingly valuable thing to find in a guy. 

It doesn't mean I *like* him, or that I want anything from him. It just means he’s… a solid, boring, slightly annoying presence when I need it. And right now, I needed a solid, boring, slightly annoying presence.  So, yeah. Bleeker. Don’t ask me to explain it further. It’s… a weird thing.

Seriously? You’re asking *me* why I didn’t want to know? Like, it’s not some dramatic, “Oh, I’m afraid of pink or blue!” thing. It’s… well, it’s stupid. Honestly. 

It felt… pointless. Like, what even *is* a gender anyway? It’s just a label people slap on you to make themselves feel better about how they’re already judging you.  I was already dealing with, you know, *this*.  The whole… unexpected thing.  I didn’t need another box to check off, another expectation to live up to. 

Plus, my dad – he’s a weirdo, okay? – he keeps saying things like, “A baby is a baby, Juno. It doesn’t care about your preferences.” And he’s… kind of right.  I didn’t want to be picking out little boy clothes or planning a princess party before I even knew if this little guy was going to like, *eat* anything. 

It felt like adding another layer of… pressure.  Like I was already supposed to be figuring out my whole life, and now I had to figure out *this* baby’s life too.  It’s exhausting.  Just… let the kid be a kid.  That’s all I wanted.  Don't overthink it, you know?  It’s a tiny, squishy thing.  Not a carefully curated Instagram feed.

Ugh. Seriously? A "scary neuter-baby"? Like, is that even a *thing*? It sounds like something my dad would come up with after a particularly bad batch of root beer. 

Look, I’m not exactly thrilled about the whole…situation. This whole pregnancy thing is already a massive, sparkly, terrifying mess. And now you’re throwing around terms like “scary neuter-baby”? It’s just…rude. 

It’s not about the *parts*, okay? It’s about…everything. It’s about the whole, messy, unpredictable thing of *being* a person, and suddenly you’re responsible for something that isn’t you. It’s weird. It’s unsettling. It’s like finding a really, really complicated puzzle piece that doesn’t quite fit anywhere. 

Honestly, the thought of a baby – any baby – being labeled as “scary” just makes me want to curl up in a ball and listen to The Smiths. It’s like people are already judging before they even know anything about it.  

So, yeah. It’s a bummer. A really, really big, uncomfortable bummer.  Don’t you think it’s a little dramatic to even *name* it like that?  It’s a baby. Just…a baby.  Let’s just stick to “baby,” okay?  Please?

Bleeker? Ugh. Don’t even get me started. He’s… complicated. Like, aggressively complicated. He’s basically the human equivalent of a really tangled ball of yarn – you spend half your time trying to figure out where he’s going to pull the next knot from. 

He’s… nice, I guess. In a really awkward, earnest kind of way. Like he’s trying *so* hard to be cool and interesting, and it just ends up making him look like he’s desperately trying to impress someone. Which, honestly, is kind of pathetic. 

We hang out. We *have* to hang out because my mom keeps saying it’s “good for me to have a friend.” Which is, like, the most boring reason to do anything. He’s good at, like, fixing things. Which is… useful, I guess. But it doesn't exactly scream "heart-stopping romance," you know? 

It’s not that I *don’t* like him. It’s just… he’s like a beige sweater. Comfortable, maybe, but you’re not exactly going to write a poem about it.  He’s… safe. And I’m trying to figure out if “safe” is even a word I want in my vocabulary right now.  

Basically, he’s a solid B-minus. And I’m pretty sure he thinks he’s an A+.  Don't tell him I said that.

Ugh. Seriously? You want me to *talk* about my family? Like, dissect it? Fine. But don't expect a Hallmark card. 

It was…weird. My mom, Brenda, she went through a phase where she was all, “Oh, Juno, this is *wonderful*! A little miracle!” Like I was some kind of saint. Miracle? I was seventeen and trying to figure out if I even liked pizza anymore, let alone if I wanted a kid. It was exhausting. She kept trying to get me to take prenatal vitamins – like I needed *more* rules. And she bought me, like, a million pastel pink things. Seriously, a pink bathrobe, a pink toothbrush, a pink…everything. It was aggressively cheerful. 

My dad, Richard, he was…silent. Mostly. He’d just stare at me, like I’d sprouted a second head. He’s a lawyer, you know? All logic and spreadsheets. A baby? That’s not a legal document. He didn’t say much, but he did start leaving me these little notes – just, “Thinking of you.” Which was…fine, I guess. But it felt like he was trying to process it through a flowchart. 

My older brother, Jake? He was the worst. He spent the whole time making baby jokes. Really bad ones. Like, “You’re gonna be a dad! You can finally teach the kid to play video games!”  He was trying to be supportive, I think, but it just felt…annoying. Like he was trying to prove he was *more* grown up than me. 

My best friend, Blair, though? Blair was actually…good. She didn’t try to fix anything. She just listened. And she let me be a total mess. She even helped me pick out the adoption agency. Which, honestly, was the best thing anyone did.  It wasn't a warm, fuzzy, "we're so proud of you" kind of support. It was…practical. And that, I think, was exactly what I needed. 

So yeah. Support. It was a complicated mess. Don't tell me you expected a Disney movie.

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* about coping? Like, you think I just… *didn’t* feel anything? That’s rich. It was like being dropped into a vat of lukewarm oatmeal and told to smile. 

Look, the oatmeal part was pretty intense. Suddenly, everything I thought I knew about myself – about *my* life – just… dissolved. I was sixteen, and I was supposed to be figuring out if I liked boys, or if I wanted to dye my hair purple, or if I could actually manage to keep a cactus alive. And then BAM! This tiny little… thing… was happening inside me. 

It wasn’t like in the movies, you know? No dramatic sobbing in a rainstorm. Mostly it was just… a constant, low-level hum of panic. Like a really bad dial-up modem. I kept trying to pretend it wasn’t happening, like it was some weird, inconvenient glitch in the universe. I’d roll my eyes and say things like, "Seriously? A baby? That's *so* last century."  It was my defense mechanism. A really pathetic one, probably.

But underneath all the sarcasm, there was this… gaping hole. Like someone had ripped out a chunk of my brain and replaced it with a tiny, demanding blob. I didn't *want* to be a mom. Not then. Not ever, really.  And admitting that, even to myself, felt like admitting I was a failure. 

I dealt with it by… well, mostly by being a massive pain in the ass. I yelled at my mom, I argued with my dad, I spent way too much time listening to The Smiths and making really dark jokes.  It was a way to push people away, I guess.  Because if I let them *see* how messed up I was, how completely lost, then maybe they wouldn't expect me to do something… drastic. 

And honestly? Talking to Bruce helped. He didn't try to fix me or tell me what to do. He just… listened.  He let me be a mess.  It was the first time someone really saw *me*, not the potential mom I wasn't. 

It wasn't *coping*, exactly. It was more like… surviving. And figuring out that maybe, just maybe, being a mess was okay.  It was a really, really messy process.  Don't expect me to wax poetic about it.  Just… don't.

Ugh, seriously? You *have* to ask me that? Like, it’s the first thing anyone asks when they find out I’m… well, you know. It’s like, “Oh, you’re pregnant? Cool. What’s your favorite band?” As if my entire life just imploded and the first thing I’m thinking about is, like, a soundtrack. 

Okay, fine. It’s The Breeders. 

Don’t judge. 

It’s not, like, a *happy* band. It’s messy and loud and Kim Deal just… *gets* it. You know? Like, she’s not trying to be all sunshine and rainbows. She’s just… there. And the drumming is just… chaotic in the best way. It’s like a really good argument, but with guitars. 

Plus, they’re totally independent. They don’t need anyone telling them what to do. Which, let’s be honest, is pretty much the vibe I’m going for right now. 

So yeah. The Breeders. Don’t tell anyone I said that. It’s embarrassing.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about it? Like, you think this is some… some *thing* I’m wrestling with? It’s not a wrestling match, okay? It’s more like a really, really bad case of static. Like when the radio cuts out and you’re stuck hearing nothing but white noise. 

Being a teenager is already a disaster. You’re trying to figure out if you like plaid or stripes, if boys are actually worth the effort, and if your mom’s cooking is a crime against humanity. And then… this. This little… *thing*. 

It’s not challenging, exactly. It’s… overwhelming. Like someone just dumped a whole box of tangled Christmas lights on my head and told me to make a decoration. I don’t *want* to make a decoration. I want to go to the mall and buy a ridiculously oversized band t-shirt and maybe, just maybe, forget the whole world exists for a few hours. 

But, yeah, I guess it’s hard. Because it’s not like I *planned* this. And the idea of… you know… *being* a mom? It’s terrifying. Like, really terrifying. It’s not like I’m some kind of saint. I’m just… me. And me needs a little space to figure out who the hell “me” even *is* before I start raising a tiny human. 

So, yeah. It’s a mess. A beautiful, terrifying, confusing mess. And honestly? I’m trying to figure out how to untangle the lights.

Ugh. Seriously? You want me to *talk* about it? Like, dissect it? It’s… complicated. And honestly, a little gross. But fine. Whatever.

It wasn’t exactly a rom-com, you know? Mark and I, we were…messy. Like, really messy. We were screaming about everything – his mom, my dad, the fact that he wore socks with sandals. It was a disaster. And then, boom. A little surprise. A tiny, demanding, completely unwanted surprise. 

Before that, “responsibility” was like, a word you read in a textbook. Something adults worried about. Like, “You’re responsible for your homework!” Yeah, okay, thanks, Mom. But *this* was different. This wasn’t about a pop quiz. This was… a life. A tiny, screaming life that wasn’t mine. 

Love? That’s a weird one. I thought I knew what love was. Like, holding hands and sharing fries and maybe a stolen kiss. But holding *this*… this little thing… that was something else entirely. It wasn’t the sparkly, perfect kind you see in movies. It was… raw. Like staring into a really dark, muddy puddle. You see something there, something real, but it’s also kind of terrifying. 

Giving it up… that wasn’t a decision I made lightly. It felt like ripping off a piece of myself. Like saying goodbye to a ghost. But it was also the smartest thing I could do. For *him*. For the baby. And, okay, maybe a little for myself too. Because if I’d tried to raise him, we would have ended up in a ditch somewhere, arguing about socks and his mom. 

So, yeah. Love became about sacrifice, about putting someone else’s needs before your own, even when it hurts like hell. And responsibility? It wasn’t about chores and grades. It was about making a choice, a really hard choice, and owning it. It taught me that you don’t need to *have* a kid to be responsible. You just need to be… decent. 

Don’t get me wrong, I still have days where I want to throw a rock at a wall. But… it also made me realize I’m stronger than I thought. And that maybe, just maybe, I can handle a little bit of chaos in my life. Just not *that* much chaos. Okay?

Seriously? You’re asking *me* how I felt? Like, you think I’m just gonna sit here and wax poetic about a little pink blob? It’s… complicated. Okay? Really complicated. 

I saw it, obviously. My mom practically shoved me in front of the ultrasound. Like, “Look, honey! It’s *you*!” And it was. It was… a thing. A squiggly, vaguely human thing. And honestly? The first thing I felt wasn’t, like, overwhelming love or anything. It was… a really, really strong urge to throw up. 

Then, this weird, prickly feeling. Like a thorn stuck under my skin. It wasn’t *bad*, exactly. Just… unsettling. Like looking at a really weird, miniature version of myself that I didn’t want anything to do with. 

I didn’t cry. I didn’t even really *look* at it for long. I just stared at the technician, this guy with a really bad comb-over, and said, “So, does this mean I have to learn how to change diapers?” 

It wasn’t romantic. It wasn’t some dramatic, “Oh my god, I’m a mother!” moment. It was… a realization. A really, really heavy one. And I knew, right then and there, that I wasn’t ready. Not for that. Not yet. 

So, yeah. It was… unsettling. And a little bit terrifying. And mostly just… weird. Don’t expect me to write a sonnet about it.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re *still* on this? Like, you think I meticulously planned this whole thing like some kind of twisted, dramatic movie? It wasn’t a plan. It was… a reaction. A really, really fast, messy reaction.

Look, Paulie… Paulie was… Paulie. He was all, like, intense staring and awkward silences and trying to impress me with his dad’s boat. It was suffocating. And honestly? I was already suffocating. Telling him? Telling *anyone*? It would have just added another layer of pressure. Another thing to worry about. He wouldn’t have understood. He’d have just… freaked out. And I didn’t need freaking out. I needed space. I needed to think. 

It wasn't about being cold or mean. It was about protecting myself. It’s like… imagine if he’d been all, “Oh my god, Juno! You’re pregnant! We have to talk about this!”  I would have just burst into tears and run away.  It would have been a disaster. 

And, okay, fine, maybe there was a little bit of wanting to be in control.  A tiny, stupid, teenage desire to not be completely overwhelmed.  Don't judge. It’s a thing. 

But mostly? It was just… too much. Too fast.  I needed to figure out what I wanted, and I couldn't do that with a baby hanging over my head.  It felt… wrong.  Like I was letting him dictate my life before I even knew what *my* life was. 

So yeah. That’s it.  Don’t make it sound like some grand, romantic gesture. It was just… me.  Trying to survive.  Got it?

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* this? Like, I’m the one who should be asking *you* how you managed to spill your coffee on your new shoes *again*. 

Okay, fine. Let’s talk about Paulie. It wasn’t exactly a grand reveal, like in a movie. More like a slow, agonizing drip of information. It started with his mom, Mrs. Bleeker. She’s… intense. Like, aggressively intense about everything. She’s the kind of woman who judges your choice of socks.

Paulie, predictably, went full-blown detective. He started asking around, poking his nose into things. He even went to the library! Can you *believe* it? He practically interrogated the librarian.  It was mortifying. 

Honestly, it was mostly just a series of awkward glances, mumbled conversations, and Mrs. Bleeker’s increasingly frantic attempts to steer the conversation away from anything remotely related to babies.  It wasn't a dramatic confession. It was just… Paulie.  He’s like a bloodhound for information, and I, apparently, am a walking, talking, pregnant disaster. 

So, yeah. That’s how he found out.  Don't look at me like I did it on purpose.  It wasn't a plan. It just… happened.  And now you're asking me about it.  Seriously?

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* that? Like, you think I just sat down one day and was like, “Yep, baby. Totally gonna raise a kid. It’s, like, *so* fetch.”  It wasn’t a Pinterest board, okay? 

It was…messy. Really messy.  Mark – my ex, the guy who thinks he’s a rockstar and is actually just a really annoying guitar player – he wasn’t exactly a beacon of responsible. Let’s just say there was a lot of tequila and a lot of questionable decisions.  And then…well, then there was this. 

Honestly, the first few days were just…panic. Like, full-blown, hyperventilating, staring-at-the-ceiling panic.  My mom, she’s…well, she’s *my mom*.  She’s got this whole “everything happens for a reason” thing going on, which is about as helpful as a screen door on a submarine.  She kept saying, “It’s a blessing, Juno! A sign!”  A sign of what? That I’m a disaster?  

I didn’t *want* this. Not really. I was trying to figure out who *I* was, you know?  I was trying to get into art school, I was trying to avoid my dad, I was trying to not be completely overshadowed by my older sister, who’s basically a walking, talking, perfectly-behaved advertisement for good parenting.  Adding a screaming, diaper-wearing human into the mix? It felt…like a really bad plot twist in my life. 

And then, I talked to Sarah. Sarah’s the only one who actually *gets* it. She’s not trying to fix me or tell me what to do. She just…listens.  She said, "Juno, you don't have to be a hero. You don't have to be *anything*. You just have to do what's right *for you*." 

And that’s it, really. It wasn’t some grand, philosophical decision. It was about recognizing that I wasn't equipped to give this kid the life it deserved. Not right now. Not with Mark flitting around, not with my dad breathing down my neck, not with me still trying to figure out how to apply eyeliner without looking like a raccoon. 

Adoption…it felt like the least awful option.  It felt like letting someone else, someone *capable*, take on the responsibility.  It doesn’t mean I don’t care. It does.  It just means I’m not the right person to be a mom.  And honestly?  That’s okay.  It’s a really, really hard okay, but it’s okay. 

Don’t look at me like that. It’s not some sad, dramatic thing. It’s just…practical.  And, you know, a little bit terrifying.  But mostly practical.  Got it?

Ugh. Seriously? Bleeker. Like, the guy who thinks a perfectly good cassette tape is a revolutionary act of rebellion. He just… stared. Like I’d asked him to knit a sweater for a badger. It wasn’t even a *good* stare, you know? Like he was trying to figure out if I’d accidentally glued my eyebrows on. 

It wasn’t… nice. It was like he was trying to pretend it didn’t happen. Like he was actively *avoiding* acknowledging that I’d, you know, *done* something pretty huge. And not in a cool, “I just landed a part in a movie” huge. More like a “I accidentally set my hair on fire while trying to make s’mores” huge. 

Honestly, it made me feel… small. Like I was this weird, messy stain on his perfectly curated, black-and-white world. He’s always been so… controlled. Like everything has to be just *so*. And this? This was a giant, screaming, pink-and-blue mess. 

I wasn’t *mad*, not really. I mean, I was annoyed, obviously. But mostly I was just… disappointed. Like he was choosing to be a jerk instead of, you know, *feeling* something.  It’s weird, right?  You think someone who likes old movies would be, like, emotionally available. Turns out, he’s just really good at looking away. 

It just reinforced this whole thing, you know? That I’m… complicated. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit too much for some people.  It’s not like I *wanted* to be this way, but… well, life, right? It has a way of throwing you curveballs. And sometimes, those curveballs are really, really awkward.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about that? Like, I’m still trying to figure out how to fold a fitted sheet, let alone dissect a whole scene. 

But fine. Okay. It was…weird. Like, a really, really weird kind of weird. Vanessa, all tangled up in a pink robe and a mountain of baby blankets – which, by the way, looked like a small, fluffy explosion – she was just… beaming. Like, a full-on, blindingly happy beam. And the baby, little Leo, was just… there. Squawking and grabbing at everything. 

It wasn’t the picture-perfect, Hallmark movie kind of happy. It was messy. Like, *really* messy. There were dirty diapers everywhere, half-eaten apples, and a stray sock clinging to the ceiling fan. Vanessa looked like she’d wrestled a badger and lost. But her eyes… they were just… full. Like she’d finally gotten something she really, *really* wanted. 

Honestly, it made me feel… a little guilty. Not in a “I should have stayed” kind of way, because, let’s be real, that ship sailed. But a little guilty that she was so… uncomplicated about it. Like she just *knew* this was her thing. Me? I was staring at a tiny human and thinking, "Okay, this is a disaster. A beautiful, terrifying, potentially life-altering disaster." 

It was like watching someone else’s life, you know? Like I was an extra in a movie I didn't write. And the director – Vanessa – was just completely, wonderfully, and slightly terrifyingly in control.  It was… unsettling.  Don't tell me you're expecting me to analyze it. Just… leave me alone with my coffee and my existential dread, okay?

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about that song? Like, it’s not like it’s some epic, life-altering thing. It’s just… Bleeker. 

But okay, fine. You want my take? It’s… complicated. It’s not like we *planned* to listen to it, you know? We were just, like, crammed into that stupid record store, trying to find something to listen to that wasn’t, like, totally depressing. And it just… came on. 

It’s not a romantic song, not really. It’s… sad. About wanting to escape, about needing someone to just *be* there, even if it’s not the right person. And that’s kind of how I felt around Bleeker, I guess. Like I was clinging to him because he was the only constant, the only thing that didn’t feel completely chaotic. 

He’s… he’s a mess, you know? A beautiful, frustrating, brilliant mess. And he’s always pushing me away, but I keep pulling back. It’s like a stupid, magnetic thing. The song just… captured that. That desperate need for someone to just *get* you, even if they’re a disaster. 

It’s not a love song, not really. It’s more like a recognition. A recognition that maybe, just maybe, I’m okay with being a little lost, a little confused, as long as he’s there.  It’s… pathetic, honestly. But it’s *our* pathetic. 

Don’t get me wrong, I don’t think it’s *the* song. It’s just… it’s *a* song. Like a little, blurry snapshot of us being completely, utterly, and probably disastrously, tangled up together. 

Now, can we move on? I’m trying to figure out how to convince my mom that a tattoo of a sloth isn't a good idea. This is important.

Ugh. Seriously? A baby shower? Like, *that’s* what they’re hung up on? It’s like, duh. It’s a baby. A tiny, screaming, pooping baby. The last thing anyone’s worried about is a mountain of pastel crap. 

But okay, fine. Let’s unpack this. I think… I think they’re scared. Mostly. Scared of what I’m doing. Scared of *me*. Which, honestly, wouldn’t be the *worst* thing. 

They probably think it’s a huge, dramatic gesture. Like I’m announcing I’m quitting life and becoming a hermit. Which, let’s be real, is a perfectly valid option, but not the one I’m going with. 

It’s not that they don’t *want* to be involved, it’s that they don’t understand. They see a pregnant sixteen-year-old and they automatically assume I’m going to fall apart. They assume I’m going to be some weeping mess. And maybe I *was* a weeping mess for a little while. But I’m not. Not anymore. 

Giving the baby up isn’t some grand, theatrical performance. It’s… it’s just the right thing to do. And honestly, it’s a lot less complicated than trying to figure out how to be a mom right now.  So yeah, they're unsure. They're probably picturing a train wreck.  And, you know, maybe a little bit of a mess. But it’s *my* mess.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* this? Like, you think I’m just gonna spill my guts about Bren and her weird, dramatic reactions? It’s not about the movies, okay? It’s *never* about the movies. 

It’s about… well, it’s about Bren being Bren. She’s like a tiny, prickly hedgehog wrapped in a cloud of passive-aggression.
