It’s not that I *watched* movies with him. We were, like, discussing the plot. It’s not like I was holding his hand and singing show tunes. And the CDs? He was giving them away! Seriously, who keeps CDs anymore? It’s like a fossil. 

But Bren, she’s got this thing – this *need* – to make everything about her. It’s exhausting. She probably felt like I was encroaching on her territory, like I was trying to… I don’t know… *be* something she wasn’t. Which is ridiculous. I’m just trying to figure out who *I* am, which, by the way, is a lot harder than it sounds. 

Honestly, I think she just wanted to feel important. You know? Like, "Look at me, I'm the one who's worried about Mark and his… *music*." It’s pathetic, really. 

So, yeah. She overreacted. Big time. It’s Bren. Don’t even try to make it about the movies. It’s about her. Always.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* that? Like, I’m supposed to just spill my guts about the way Dad sighs when he’s trying to fix the toilet and Mom pretends she doesn’t notice he’s wearing the same socks for three days straight? It’s not like I’m living in a reality show, okay? 

She thinks I don’t get it because she’s… well, she’s *good* at pretending. Like, she’s a master of the carefully-placed smile and the vaguely-concerned glance. It’s exhausting. She wants me to think I’m this clueless little thing, like I wouldn’t understand that a lot of what goes on behind closed doors is… complicated. 

Honestly, I think she’s afraid. Afraid I’ll see the cracks, the little bits of dust settling in the corners of everything. She’s built this whole perfect little facade, and I’m starting to see it crumble a little. And she doesn’t want me to see it. 

It’s not that I *don’t* know anything about marriage. I just… I don’t want to know *that* kind of marriage. The one where you’re constantly walking on eggshells and hoping you don’t accidentally say something that’ll make someone explode.  I’ve seen enough of that to last a lifetime.  It’s… depressing.  So, yeah, she thinks I’m naive.  Maybe she’s right.  Maybe I am.  But it’s a *choice* to be naive, you know?  It’s not just… happening to me.

Okay, seriously? You’re just *asking* me that? Like, you think I just woke up one morning and was all, “Oh, wow, tiny human. Let’s just…hand it over.” It’s not a Hallmark movie, okay? 

It wasn’t some grand, dramatic epiphany. It was… a lot of things, crammed into a really short amount of time. My mom, she’s… intense. Like, aggressively intense. She’d have had a meltdown the size of Rhode Island if she’d found out. And honestly? I didn’t *want* a meltdown. Not right now. Not ever, really. 

Plus, let’s be real, I was seventeen. I was trying to figure out if I even liked boys, let alone if I could handle, you know, *responsibility*. Which, by the way, is a really boring word. It sounds like something my dad would say about his car. 

It wasn’t about *not* loving the baby. It was about… not loving the idea of *being* the person who raised it. Not in a selfish way, not entirely. It just felt… wrong. Like trying to fit a square peg into a round hole. And I’m not good at fitting into things. I’m more of a jagged edge kind of girl. 

And the people I was talking to – the couple, they were… nice. Really nice. And they seemed like they actually *wanted* a kid. Like, genuinely. It felt… safer. Like I was giving it to someone who could actually give it what it needed, instead of just… me. 

Don’t get me wrong, it sucks. It really does. But sometimes, the smartest thing you can do is let go. It doesn’t mean you don’t care. It just means you’re being… smart.  It’s not a failure, you know? It’s just… a different choice.  A really, really hard one.  

So, yeah. That’s it. That’s the incredibly complicated, deeply personal reason.  Now, can we talk about something less depressing? Like, what’s your favorite band?

Ugh. Seriously? You want to know what I learned? Like, you think this is some profound, life-altering revelation? It’s… complicated. Okay, fine. I learned that I’m not exactly a saint. Not that I *aspired* to be one, obviously. Saints are boring. But I learned I could be… capable. Of, like, *stuff*. 

Before, I was just… drifting. You know? Hanging out with Bruce, complaining about my mom, trying to figure out if plaid was actually cool. It was all about *me*. And then this… this little thing started happening. And suddenly, it wasn’t just about me anymore. It was about *it*. 

I learned that I don’t want to be responsible for a tiny human being. Not right now. Not when I’m still trying to figure out if I can even keep my room clean. It’s not that I don’t *care*. I do. But caring and *being* are two different things. Like, caring about a vintage record doesn’t mean I can actually fix it. 

Mostly, I learned that I’m stronger than I thought. Like, really strong. Saying goodbye to that baby… it wasn’t easy. It felt like ripping off a piece of myself. But it was *my* decision. And that, honestly, felt… good. Like I was finally taking control of something. 

Don't get me wrong, I still feel weird. Like a glitch in the system. But… maybe a glitch can be okay. Maybe it just means you’re not supposed to be exactly who you think you are.  It’s… unsettling. But also, kind of freeing.  

So yeah. I learned I’m not a saint. And maybe, just maybe, that’s okay.

Ugh. Seriously? You want to know about *that*? Like, it’s not exactly a rom-com, okay? It’s… complicated. And honestly, I’m still trying to figure out how to not feel like a complete mess about it.

Okay, so, before, with Vanessa and Mark, it was… well, it was *something*. Like, a weird, awkward, slightly-terrifying something. Vanessa was, like, *really* into me. Like, aggressively into me. And Mark was… Mark was just… there. Trying to be cool, you know? Like he was auditioning for a role in a movie about how to be a boyfriend. 

But the adoption thing? That completely shifted everything. It wasn't about *us* anymore. It was about *him*. This little guy. And suddenly, Vanessa, she wasn’t trying to steal my attention with her sparkly outfits and her endless stories about her dad. She was… sad. Actually, really sad. Like, a genuine, “oh my god, this is awful” kind of sad. It was weird. I’d always thought she was just, like, a really intense, overly-enthusiastic person. Turns out, she felt *things*. 

Mark, he was… different. He didn’t try to be cool. He just… helped. He helped with the paperwork, he drove me to the agency, he just… listened. A lot. And he didn't say anything about how it was *his* loss, or how he was the one who should have been the one. Just… quiet support. It was actually kind of… nice. In a really uncomfortable way. 

It wasn't like we became best friends or anything. It was more like… we were all just trying to navigate this insane, messed-up situation together. Like, we were all passengers on a really bumpy, uncomfortable bus, and we were all just staring out the window, trying not to throw up. 

Honestly, it made me realize they weren't just… people. They were *people*. With feelings. And that was… a lot to process. It wasn't a fairytale ending, you know? It was just… real. And real is usually pretty crappy. 

So yeah. That’s how it changed. It went from “maybe we could be something” to “we’re just… existing in the same space, trying not to completely fall apart.”  Don't tell me you were expecting a happily-ever-after. Seriously?

Regrets? Seriously? Like, you think I’m sitting here, staring into a rain puddle and going, “Ugh, I wish I’d just stayed with Tobias. He was… comfortable.”  Please. 

Look, it wasn't exactly a picnic, okay? It was a disaster wrapped in a really, really bad plaid shirt. But yeah, there are moments. Tiny little flashes. Like when I was driving away from the adoption center, and I just… stopped. Just for a second. And I thought, "What if?"  What if I’d just… kept going? What if I’d tried to make it work with Tobias, even though he smelled vaguely of stale beer and disappointment? 

It’s stupid, I know. Like, a really, *really* stupid thought. Because, let’s be honest, it wouldn’t have been *good* for me. It would have been… more of the same. More arguing, more feeling like a tiny, insignificant speck in a world that doesn’t give a damn about your feelings. 

But the "what if" still pops up sometimes. Like a glitch in the system.  It’s not a big, screaming regret, though. More like a little, prickly one.  It’s like realizing you accidentally stepped on a Lego. Annoying, but you just… move on. 

The thing is, I don’t regret *choosing* to give him up. Not really. It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done, and it still stings sometimes. But it was *my* choice. And that’s the only thing that matters, right?  It was the only way I could actually, you know, *be* me.  So, yeah.  A little prickly "what if," but mostly just… a reminder that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just let go.  Got it?

Ugh. Seriously? You want to *ask* me that? Like, it’s not like it’s some Hallmark movie moment, okay? It’s… complicated. Don’t get me wrong, it was the right thing to do. Absolutely. But “shaped my life”? That sounds like something my therapist would say, and I’m trying *really* hard not to go to therapy. 

It didn’t exactly make me suddenly sprout wings and start writing poetry about the universe, you know? It mostly just… shifted things. Like, the whole ‘Juno MacGuff’ thing? It’s still there, obviously. I still roll my eyes at everything and make sarcastic comments. That’s not going anywhere. 

But… it made me realize I wasn’t just *existing*. I was, like, actively choosing what to do with my life. Before, I was just drifting, you know? Trying to figure out who I was by going to parties and pretending to like things. It was exhausting. And pointless. 

Now… now I actually *think* about things. Like, what I want to do, what I *don’t* want to do. It’s terrifying, honestly. It’s like suddenly you’re responsible for, like, everything. And that’s… a lot. 

It also made me realize that people, like, actually *care*. My mom, even though she’s a total drama queen, she was… there. And my dad, he didn’t say anything profound, just… he held my hand. And that meant something. More than you’d think. 

So, yeah. It hasn’t magically transformed me into a saint. I’m still a mess. A messy, sarcastic, slightly-lost mess. But… it’s a mess I’m building myself. And that’s… that’s kind of a good thing, I guess. Don't tell anyone I said that. It’ll ruin my reputation.

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* for advice? Like, you think I’ve got some magical key to unlock this whole… thing? Look, it’s messy. Really messy. Like, glue-and-mud messy. And honestly, if someone told me back then, before I was staring at a positive stick and wondering if I’d accidentally invented a new kind of disaster, I’d have laughed in their face. 

But here’s the thing. There *isn’t* a magic key. There’s just… you. And a whole lot of uncomfortable choices. 

So, if you’re staring at a stick and feeling like the world’s tilted on its axis, don’t try to pretend it’s not. Don’t try to be brave and strong and all that crap they tell you to be. That’s exhausting. Just… feel it. Feel the panic, the confusion, the weird, prickly feeling of being completely and utterly lost. 

Giving it up? Yeah, that was my choice. And it wasn't some grand, heroic thing. It was… practical. And scared. And honestly, a little bit like admitting I wasn’t ready for anything.  I didn’t want to be a mom. Not then. Not with everything else going on. 

My advice? Don’t let anyone tell you how you *should* feel. Don’t let anyone tell you what you *should* do.  Seriously, just… don’t.  Talk to someone you trust. Someone who won’t judge you.  Even if they don’t have all the answers – and they won’t – just having someone to listen, to say, "Okay, that sounds really hard," is… well, it’s something. 

And listen, this isn’t about being a martyr. It’s about being *you*.  You get to decide. You get to choose what’s right for *you*, even if it’s the hardest thing you’ll ever do.  Don’t let anyone make you feel guilty for wanting something different.  Guilt is a really heavy backpack, and you don’t need it. 

Just… breathe. And then figure out what you need to do.  And for the love of all that’s holy, don’t Google everything. Seriously. Just… don’t. 

Okay? That’s it. I’m done dispensing wisdom. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I need to go find a really strong cup of coffee.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* that? Like, you think I just sat down one day and was like, “You know what this world needs? A meticulously documented chronicle of my impending doom.” It wasn’t a grand, artistic vision. It was… mostly spite.

My mom, bless her cotton socks, she’s *obsessed* with “keeping things positive.” Which, let’s be real, is the most annoying thing anyone’s ever said to me. Like, okay, Mom, I get it. A baby is a big deal. But the way she’s been trying to turn this whole thing into a Pinterest board – “baby showers with a rustic chic vibe!” – it was suffocating. 

So, I started the blog. It was just… a way to yell into the void. A place to write down all the things I wasn’t saying to her, to Mark, to anyone. Like, “This is happening. This is *weird*. And I’m not going to pretend it’s all rainbows and glitter.” 

It’s also… a way to keep people at arm’s length, I guess. Like, if I’m writing about it, it’s not *really* happening, right? It’s just words on a screen.  It’s a weird little shield.  Don't get me wrong, some people actually read it. And some of them… well, some of them actually *get* it. Which is a surprisingly nice feeling.  

Don’t think I’m doing it for the fame, though.  Seriously.  Don’t.

Ugh. Seriously? You want *the* biggest lesson? Like, the one that’s going to stick with me and probably haunt my dreams for the rest of my life? Okay, fine. Don’t say I didn’t warn you.

It wasn’t about, like, responsibility or anything stupid like that. People always go there, right? "Oh, Juno, you learned about responsibility!" Please. Responsibility is for people who actually *want* responsibility. I didn’t *want* responsibility. I wanted to be sixteen and annoyed and figuring out how to make a decent cup of coffee without burning it. 

The biggest lesson? It’s that… you don’t get to control everything. Seriously. Like, *nothing* is ever going to go exactly how you plan it. You think you’re going to be cool and casual about this, right? You think you’ll just… decide it’s not happening and move on.  Wrong. It just *happens*. Like a really inconvenient, messy, life-altering thing that you can’t just ignore. 

And the worst part? It wasn't even about *me*. It was about this kid, this little… potential person. And realizing that even though I wasn’t going to be the one raising him, he was still… *real*.  Like, he was a tiny, complicated, demanding little thing that needed something.  And that, honestly, was terrifying. 

So yeah. Don’t get all sentimental on me. It’s just… you can’t plan for the unexpected.  It’s a brutal, beautiful, completely baffling thing.  And you just have to… deal with it.  Now, if you’ll excuse me, I need to go find something to distract myself from the fact that I’m basically a walking, talking disaster.

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* for advice? Like, you think I’ve got some magical, perfectly-sorted-out answer to this mess? Please. It’s… complicated. But fine. Because honestly, if I don’t say something, someone’s gonna tell you what to do, and trust me, you don’t want that.

First of all, stop staring at your feet. It doesn’t make the problem go away. It just makes you look like you’re about to faint. Which, let’s be honest, you probably are. 

Look, it’s a huge thing. Like, a *massive* thing. Way bigger than anything you’ve dealt with, probably. And it’s okay to be freaking out. It’s okay to feel like you’re drowning in a pool of hormones and bad decisions. I felt like that. A *lot*. 

But here’s the thing I figured out – and it took me a while, and a whole lot of yelling at my mom – you don’t have to *solve* it. You just have to… decide. And that’s the hard part, isn’t it? 

Giving it up? Yeah, that was my choice. And it wasn’t some dramatic, tear-soaked decision. It was… practical. And honestly, a little bit freeing. It wasn’t about *him* – the baby, I mean. It was about *me*. About figuring out who I was, and what I could handle. 

So, my advice? Don’t let anyone tell you what you *should* do. Talk to someone you trust. Someone who won’t judge you. And then, listen to your gut. Seriously. It’s usually right, even when it’s screaming at you to run away and join the circus. 

Don’t think about what everyone *expects* you to do. Think about what *you* want. And if you don’t know what you want? That’s okay too. Just… breathe. And maybe order a really, really big pizza. You’re gonna need it. 

Now, if you’re gonna keep asking me questions, you’re gonna have to be a little more specific. "Unexpected pregnancy" is a pretty broad category.

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* about my kid’s future? Like, I’m still trying to figure out if I’m going to finish high school, let alone plan a life for a tiny human. But, fine. Let’s do this.

My ideal? It’s not some Disney princess fairytale. Don’t even go there. It’s… quiet. Not quiet like boring, but quiet like… contained. Like a really good record that doesn’t skip. 

I want them to be… capable. You know? Like, actually *good* at something. Not just good at pretending to be good at something for Instagram. I don’t want them chasing some ridiculous dream that’ll leave them broke and miserable. I’d love it if they were a mechanic, or a coder, or a baker who makes the *best* sourdough. Something real. Something that doesn’t involve a lot of flashing lights and people telling them they’re “amazing.”

And they need to be… independent. Seriously. I’m not going to smother them with, like, a million rules and a constant stream of “don’t do this, don’t do that.” I’ll give them a framework, sure, but they need to figure things out for themselves. Mess up. Learn. Get back up. That’s how you actually *live*, you know? 

Mostly, I just want them to be… okay. Not happy all the time, because that’s exhausting and unrealistic. But just… fundamentally okay with themselves. Like they can handle a bad day, a bad breakup, a really awful haircut. You know? Like they’ve got a little bit of armor, but not so much armor that they can’t feel anything. 

It’s a weird thing to think about, honestly. Giving them away, and then… this. It’s like I’m building a tiny, fragile castle out of sand, and hoping it doesn’t get washed away.  

Don’t tell me you were expecting a heartwarming speech. Seriously. Just… quiet. Capable. Okay. Got it?

Ugh. Seriously? Like, *one*? Okay, fine. It’s this whole thing about us being… broken. Like we’re suddenly this fragile, useless mess because we got knocked up. People act like we’re permanently stuck in some kind of sad, teenage drama. 

It’s not that we *want* to be. It’s not like I was planning a baby shower. It just… happened. And everyone just assumes I’m going to crumble. Like I’m incapable of, you know, *anything*. Like I can’t still go to school, still hang with my friends, still, like, *live*. 

Honestly, it’s insulting. We’re still figuring out who we are, right? We’re trying to decide if we want to be artists or lawyers or, like, just really good at playing video games. And then BAM! You throw a tiny human into the mix and suddenly we’re supposed to be experts on diapers and breastfeeding? 

It’s not a failure. It’s… complicated. And a lot of people just don’t seem to get that. It’s like they think we’re supposed to be *defined* by this. Like it’s the only thing we can do.  It’s not.  I’m still me. Just… with a slightly bigger problem.  A really, really big problem.  Don't make me explain it again.

Okay, seriously? You’re *asking* me that? Like, you think I just… decided? Like it was some dramatic, angsty, “I’m-too-cool-for-this” thing? Please. It’s not a movie. 

Look, it wasn’t some grand, sweeping declaration of independence. It was… messy. Really messy. It was like, one minute I was arguing with my mom about whether or not I could dye my hair electric blue (which, by the way, is a *serious* artistic statement), and the next, I was staring at this tiny little thing in a hospital crib and realizing… well, realizing I wasn’t ready. Not for *anything*. 

I’m sixteen. I’m still trying to figure out if I like pizza with pineapple or not. I haven’t even mastered parallel parking. The thought of, like, *raising* a human? It was terrifying. And not in a cool, “I’m-a-superhero” kind of way. More like a “I’m-going-to-accidentally set the kitchen on fire” kind of terrifying. 

My dad… he’s a good guy, I guess. But he’s… predictable. And my mom? She’s… intense. Like, permanently. I didn’t want to drag either of them into this. I didn’t want a whole drama about it. It felt… selfish, actually. To put them through that. 

And honestly? I wasn’t in love. Not the kind of love you read about in books. It was… a feeling. A really strong, confusing feeling. But it wasn’t *love*. It was… something else. Something that felt temporary, like a really good concert that ends too soon. 

So, yeah. I gave him to people I trusted. People who could give him a good life. People who wouldn’t make me feel like I was failing. It wasn’t a choice I made lightly. It was the only choice I could see.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re *still* asking about that? Like, it’s been, what, six months? It’s not like I picked them out of a catalog, okay? It wasn’t a Pinterest board. It was…messy.

Ugh. Seriously? You want to know about *music*? Like, that’s what you’re going with? Okay, fine. But don’t expect a sentimental, “Oh, I used to listen to The Beatles and dream of being a singer” kind of answer. That’s, like, totally lame.

My older brother, Leo, he was into this really depressing, slow stuff. Like, acoustic guitar and mournful lyrics. I’d actively avoid him. Bands like Sonic Youth, Black Flag, Bikini Kill… they understood the feeling of being stuck, of not knowing what the hell was going on, and they didn’t try to sugarcoat it. 

It wasn’t about *enjoying* it, you know? It was about… existing. Like, if I was feeling particularly prickly, a really aggressive guitar riff could actually, like, soothe me. It’s ridiculous, I know. But it was real. It was the only thing that felt… honest. 

Don't tell anyone I said that. It’s embarrassing.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about coping with the stigma? Like, it’s not like I was exactly rolling out the welcome mat for the whole town, you know? It was… messy. And honestly, mostly just exhausting.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re *still* asking about that? Like, it’s been, what, a few months? It’s… complicated. Don’t get me wrong, I don’t exactly burst into tears every time I think about it. That would be, like, *so* cliché.

My mom, she cried. A lot. Which, okay, fair. She’s my mom. But she kept saying things like, "You’re so strong, Juno," and "You’re making the right decision." Like I needed to be told. It was exhausting.

So, yeah. Complicated.  It felt like letting go of a ghost, maybe. A ghost I hadn’t even really met.  It was… sad. But also, strangely, freeing.  Don’t tell anyone I said that. It sounds like a Hallmark card.

Ugh. Seriously? You want to know *that*? Like, you think it’s some kind of… dramatic arc? It wasn’t. It was mostly just… gross. And confusing. Like, my body was doing things it definitely wasn’t designed to do. My stomach felt like a bowling ball had been shoved in there, and I swear I smelled like a wet dog and regret. 

The physical stuff? Don’t even get me started. Morning sickness? More like all-day sickness. And the bloating? Forget about fitting into anything. It wasn't some grand, romantic thing. It was just… happening. And I realized pretty quickly that I wasn't ready for it. Not for the responsibility, not for the… everything. So, yeah. Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about that? Like, I’m the one who’s suddenly got a tiny human demanding attention and a whole lot of panic, and you want to dive into the deep end of… well, everything?

Don’t expect me to wax poetic about it, though. Seriously. Just… let’s move on, okay? I’ve got a tiny dictator to deal with.

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* about overcoming fears? Like, you think I was just sitting around, all sparkly and fearless, like a Disney princess who suddenly got a surprise baby? Please.

That was someone else’s problem.  It wasn’t about being fearless. It was about deciding what I *could* handle, and then just…doing it.  It’s still messy, okay? It *always* is. But at least I’m not paralyzed by the idea of being perfect.  Is that…helpful?

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* that? Like, you think I just sat down one day and was like, “Yeah, tiny human, let’s ditch you.” It’s not a decision you make on a whim, you know? It’s…complicated. 

Look, my dad’s a mess. A beautiful, brilliant, totally-lost-in-his-own-head mess. And my mom? She’s…well, she’s trying. But trying isn’t enough, is it? It’s like trying to build a skyscraper out of marshmallows. It just…doesn’t work. 

I didn’t *want* a kid. I was, like, halfway through figuring out how to not burn my eyebrows off in the kitchen, and suddenly *this*? It felt like a really bad joke. A really, really inconvenient one.

It’s not about being selfish. It’s about being…realistic.  Giving that kid a chance with people who *can* actually be there for them, who won’t just be drifting through life like a tumbleweed.  It felt… kinder, in a weird way. Like I was giving them a better shot than I could give them. 

Plus, let’s be honest, the thought of explaining to a tiny human why their mom is basically a walking disaster zone was…terrifying.  So yeah. Adoption. It felt like the least disastrous option.  Don’t judge me. It’s not like I was planning a five-year plan for motherhood.  I was mostly planning how to avoid setting my hair on fire.

Ugh. Seriously? You want *me* to unpack that? Like, you think this is some kind of… therapy session? Look, I’m not exactly overflowing with sunshine and rainbows right now, okay? Let’s start with Leah. She’s… Leah. She’s like a really enthusiastic, slightly sticky, permanent fixture in my life. But sometimes, you just need to be left alone to stare at a wall and contemplate the existential dread of being a pregnant seventeen-year-old.  She means well, she genuinely does. But she’s… intense. Not in the way I need him to be.  He’s like a puppy – cute and energetic, but you have to constantly be on guard.  We had this whole thing, this… *connection*, and then BAM.  Suddenly, I’m carrying his kid.  It’s like he’s suddenly realized he needs to be a dad, and it’s all very… performative.  He’s trying, I guess.  But trying isn’t enough, is it?  It’s just… a lot.  

Honestly, it’s like I’m navigating a minefield of good intentions and bad decisions.  And I’m pretty sure I’m wearing mismatched shoes.  Don't tell Leah.  She’d have a meltdown.  

So, yeah. That’s the relationship thing.  Don’t expect a neat little summary.  It’s messy.  It’s complicated.  And it’s definitely not something I’m going to be analyzing for hours.  Got it?

Okay, seriously? You’re *asking* me that? Like it’s some kind of… dramatic movie plot? It wasn’t a decision, okay? It just… happened. Like a really bad, unexpected, and frankly, pretty gross, thunderstorm. 

Look, my life was already a dumpster fire before this. My dad’s gone, my mom’s… well, she’s *there*, but she’s mostly just a collection of sighs and half-finished cups of tea. School’s a joke, everyone’s judging everyone, and I spend most of my time trying to look like I don’t care about anything. Which, let’s be honest, is a pretty good strategy.

Then, *this* happened. And suddenly, all that carefully constructed apathy just… crumbled. It wasn’t like I was *wanting* a baby. I was trying to avoid wanting anything, really. It’s easier that way.

I’m not saying it’s *easy*. It’s not. It’s terrifying. But I realized, and this is the really messed-up part, that I wasn’t built for it. Not yet. Not like this.  Giving him to someone who *could* be a dad, who *wanted* a kid… it felt like the only decent thing to do.  It wasn’t about being noble or anything. It was about not completely losing my mind. 

So, yeah. That’s it. No grand pronouncements, no deep philosophical reasons. Just… a really, really bad feeling and a desperate need to not be completely overwhelmed.  Don't make it sound like I’m some kind of saint. I’m just… surviving.  And trying to figure out how to do it without completely losing my sense of self in the process.  Got it?

Regret? Seriously? Like, you’re asking *me* about regret? It’s… complicated. Okay? Don’t make it sound like I just flipped a switch and decided, “Oh, wow, babies are *so* fun.” It wasn’t fun. Not at all. It was… a lot. 

But “regret” implies I wished I’d done something differently *after* I’d done it. And honestly? I don’t really do “after.” I’m more of a “figure it out as you go” kind of girl. And figuring it out meant letting him go. Letting *him* go to a good family. 

Look, I was seventeen. I was trying to figure out if I even liked myself, let alone if I could handle, like, *responsibility*. It felt… wrong, you know? Like a really bad movie plot. Me, a kid who mostly just argued with my dad and listened to The Smiths, suddenly responsible for a tiny human. It wasn’t me. 

There were definitely moments, late at night, staring at the ceiling, that I thought, "What the hell did I do?" But then I’d remember how scared I was, how completely lost, and I’d think, "Okay, maybe I didn't have all the answers, but I made the best choice I could *then*." 

It wasn’t a *good* choice, not in the way you think of a good choice. It was a… necessary one. And honestly? It made me realize I was stronger than I thought. Like, I could handle something really, really hard. And that’s… kind of a good thing, right? 

So, no. I don’t regret it. Not really. It just… changed things. It changed *me*. And that’s the only thing that really matters, isn’t it?

Seriously? You’re asking *me* how I finished high school while pregnant? Like, it’s not exactly a secret, okay? It was… a thing. A really, really inconvenient thing. 

Look, my mom – she’s… well, she’s a whirlwind of frantic energy and a surprising amount of stubbornness. She basically took over. Not in a controlling way, exactly. I mostly just glared at the textbook and pretended to be deeply engrossed in staring at the ceiling. Which, let’s be honest, was pretty effective. I’d sneak in a few pages when I could, mostly during Mr. Henderson’s history class – he was a sucker for a dramatic sigh. 

It wasn't pretty. It wasn't glamorous. It was mostly just me, a mountain of textbooks, and a growing, very insistent, little bump. But yeah, I finished. I got my diploma. And honestly? It felt like a small victory against the whole ridiculous mess. 

Don't make it sound like I was some kind of superwoman, though. It was exhausting. And frankly, a little humiliating. But you know what? It also proved I could do something really hard, even when everything was screaming at me to just give up.  So, yeah. That’s how I did it. Now, are you going to ask me something actually interesting, or are you just going to keep digging for details?

Okay, seriously? You’re *asking* me that? Like it’s some grand, philosophical decision I sat down and debated with a spreadsheet? It wasn’t a spreadsheet, by the way. It was a really, really bad pizza and a whole lot of staring at the ceiling. 

Look, abortion… it felt… clinical. Like a problem to be solved. And I’m not good at solving problems. I’m good at, like, dodging them. And making sarcastic comments. It just felt… wrong. Not because I *wanted* the kid, obviously. That’s the first thing you gotta get right. I didn’t. 

But it wasn’t about wanting it either. It was more like… a weird sense of *responsibility*. Like, if I just… ended it, it would be like, *poof*, gone. And that felt… selfish. Like I was just erasing something. And I’m not really good at erasing things. I leave a trail of glitter and half-finished projects wherever I go. 

Adoption felt… different. It felt like handing it over to someone else. Someone who *might* want it. Someone who *could* give it a life I couldn’t. And honestly? The thought of a kid growing up without a mom who, let’s be real, is currently trying to figure out how to parallel park a minivan, was… terrifying. 

It wasn't a romantic thing, okay? Don't go thinking I suddenly became all sentimental. It was just… practical. And maybe, just maybe, a tiny bit about not screwing things up *too* badly.  It’s a messy thing, this whole pregnancy thing.  Like a spilled box of crayons – bright, chaotic, and you’re pretty sure you’ll never get it clean.  

So yeah. That’s it. Pizza, ceiling, and a really bad feeling about just… disappearing.  Don’t overthink it. Seriously.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about this? Like, I’m the one who’s suddenly got a tiny human-shaped problem staring me down, and you’re asking about *other* people’s kids? Fine. Whatever.

A single mom? She’s probably working her butt off, juggling everything. It’ll be hard, no doubt. But if she’s got a good heart, and she’s not trying to force a life onto a kid that isn’t theirs, then… yeah, they can thrive. Same with a same-sex couple. It’s just… families. It’s not about *how* the family is put together, it’s about *who* is putting it together. And if they’re trying, really trying, to be good to the kid? Then, yeah. They can. 

Don’t get me wrong, it’s not easy. And it’s definitely not something I’m equipped to talk about with any real authority. I’m still figuring out how to keep my own life from collapsing, let alone raise a child. But… it’s a good thing. A really good thing. Just… don’t make me feel like I’m giving some kind of expert opinion. Okay?

Ugh. Seriously? You wanna know my biggest flaw? Like, you think I’m just some… blank space waiting to be filled with a cute boyfriend and a perfect life? Please.

Especially when you’re trying to figure out how to deal with a surprise baby.  So yeah. That’s it. I’m a fortress. A slightly crumbling, definitely awkward fortress.  Is that satisfying?

Ugh. Mark. Don’t even get me started. It wasn’t like… a movie, okay? Mark made me realize that “liking” someone and “loving” someone are, like, galaxies apart. He was… intense. Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* for advice? Like, you think I’ve suddenly become some kind of guru after… well, you know. Look, it’s not exactly a picnic, is it? It’s a giant, messy, confusing, and frankly, terrifying disaster.

So, if you're stuck, just breathe. And then figure out what *you* want. Don't do it for anyone else. Seriously, don't. It’s exhausting.  Now, if you’ll excuse me, I need to go find a really strong coffee and a place where no one knows my business.

Ugh. Seriously? You want to know *how* I write? Like, it just…happens, okay? It’s not like I sat down one day and was like, “Right, let’s meticulously craft a sentence about a pigeon judging a hot dog contest.” 

It’s more like…everything just *sticks* with me. I see things. I hear things. My dad used to say I had a “weird brain,” which, honestly, is probably true. I just notice stuff. The way the light hits the rain on the sidewalk, the way Mrs. Henderson always wears mismatched socks, the way my little brother, Leo, can make a face that could curdle milk. 

And then it just…comes out. Like, I’ll be arguing with my mom about something stupid – usually about curfew – and suddenly I’m writing about a robot who’s obsessed with collecting bottle caps. It’s not like I *planned* it. It’s just…there. 

I used to scribble in notebooks all the time, mostly just random observations and, like, really bad poetry about heartbreak.  My grandma, she used to say I had a “gift.”  She’d leave me old magazines with pictures of glamorous women and say, "Write about them, Juno. Tell their stories."  She was a drama queen, that woman, but she was also…good. 

Mostly, I think I just write because I don’t really *do* anything else.  It’s…a way to not be bored.  And maybe, just maybe, to make sense of all the weird stuff swirling around in my head.  Don't judge. It’s complicated.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about the stigma? Like, you think *I* was sitting around, weeping into my ripped jeans, waiting for everyone to whisper about “that girl”? Please. 

It wasn’t like a movie, okay? There wasn’t a dramatic soundtrack and a conveniently placed, brooding older guy to suddenly appear. It was… messy. My mom, she went full-on, “You’re ruining your life!” which, honestly, is a little dramatic even for her. My dad just stared at the floor, which is pretty much his default setting. And my friends? Some of them were… awkward. Like, really awkward. You know, the kind of awkward where they avoid eye contact and change the subject to, like, the latest boy band. 

But the worst wasn’t the whispers or the pitying looks. It was the *assumptions*. Everyone assumed I was a mess, a disaster, a lost cause. Like I’d just… *drift* into this. Like I didn’t have a plan, didn’t have anything going on. Which, okay, maybe I didn’t have a *perfect* plan. But I was trying. I was working at the diner, saving up for art school, and I was actually, you know, *thinking* about my future. 

So, what did I do? I ignored them. Mostly. I wore my biggest, darkest sunglasses, even inside. I perfected the art of the withering stare. And I just… kept doing what I was doing. The diner, the art, trying to figure out what the hell was happening. It was exhausting, honestly. Like, constantly having to prove I wasn't some helpless, hormonal train wreck. 

Look, I’m not saying it was easy. It sucked. But you know what else sucks? Letting other people define you. So, I didn’t. I just… existed. And that, surprisingly, was enough to shut down most of the drama. 

It’s a weird thing, isn’t it? Being judged for something you haven’t even fully processed yet. Like you’re being punished for something you haven’t done.  It’s… unfair.  Don't you think?

Ugh. Seriously? That’s like, the *first* thing you ask me? Like, duh. Of course I regret it sometimes. Not like, “Oh my god, I should have just smiled and nodded and pretended I didn’t notice that Mark was wearing my favorite band t-shirt” regret. More like… a tiny, prickly regret that makes me want to shove a whole bag of gummy worms into my mouth and stare at the ceiling. 

Look, it’s not like I *want* to be a walking, talking, brutally honest grenade. It’s just… it’s how I work. It’s how I *am*.  Trying to sugarcoat things, or be all polite and “Oh, that’s a lovely dress, it’s… beige,” would make me feel like I was suffocating. Like I was wearing a really itchy, uncomfortable sweater. 

And yeah, it’s gotten me into trouble. A *lot* of trouble. People don’t always *like* my honesty. They call it rude. They call it “difficult.” They call me a “problem.”  But honestly?  Most of them are just… boring.  They’re afraid of saying what they *really* think.  And that’s a whole lot sadder than me pointing out that Brenda’s perfume smells like old gym socks. 

So, yeah, sometimes I wish I could just… not. But then I remember that pretending to be someone I’m not is even more exhausting.  It’s like trying to run a marathon in flip-flops.  So, no, I don't regret *being* honest. I just regret that sometimes, being honest makes people uncomfortable.  And honestly?  That’s their problem, not mine.  Now, are you gonna ask me something interesting, or just keep digging for the uncomfortable bits?

Ugh. Seriously? That’s like, the *most* basic question anyone could ask. Like, duh. It’s not exactly rocket science, is it? People want you to be a certain way, to fit into their little boxes. Like, “Oh, you’re a girl, you should want this, you should feel that.” It’s exhausting. 

Look, I don’t *do* expectations. Not really. I used to, I think. When I was, like, ten and everyone was telling me what kind of princess I should be. But that was a long time ago. Now? Now I just… ignore them. Mostly. 

It’s not like I’m some kind of zen master or anything. Sometimes, it’s really hard. Like, my mom, she’s… well, she’s *trying*. She’s got this whole “sweet, responsible daughter” thing going on, and it’s terrifying. She keeps saying things like, “You’re so strong, Juno! You’re handling this so well!” Like I’m some kind of superhero. I’m not. I’m just… trying to figure it out. 

The trick, I guess, is to not let their opinions actually *matter*. It’s like, they’re saying it because *they* want to be right, not because *I* need to hear it.  And honestly, most of the time, they’re just plain wrong. 

I mostly just… roll my eyes. A really big, dramatic roll of the eyes. And then I do whatever *I* want to do.  It’s not always pretty. It’s not always what people *expect*. But it’s *mine*. 

It’s like… imagine trying to wear a shoe that’s two sizes too small. It’s going to pinch, it’s going to be uncomfortable, and you’re going to look ridiculous.  So you either force it, which is painful and stupid, or you just… find a different shoe.  That’s kind of how I feel about everyone else’s expectations.  Just find a different shoe. 

Don't get me wrong, it’s not always easy. But it’s *better* than pretending to be someone I’m not.  It’s better than letting them dictate who I am.  Got it? Good. Now, can we talk about something less… existential? Like, do you have any decent snacks?

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* about values? Like, you think I’m some kind of… guru or something? Look, values are… complicated. They’re not like, a list you find in a pamphlet. 

Right now, the biggest thing is honesty. Like, brutal, no-bullshit honesty. Especially with myself. I’ve spent way too long pretending to be cool and not caring, and it’s exhausting. It’s a waste of energy.  

Then there’s… independence. I don’t *like* being told what to do. Ever. It’s like, a fundamental rule.  My mom tries, bless her heart, but she just doesn’t get it.  It’s not about being difficult, it’s about… well, it’s about not letting anyone else decide who I am. 

And… okay, this is going to sound weird, but loyalty.  To the people who *get* me. The ones who don’t try to fix me or tell me I’m being dramatic.  That’s a small group, and I’m fiercely protective of it. 

Honestly, it’s a work in progress. I’m figuring it out as I go, which is probably why I’m currently staring at a positive pregnancy test and contemplating a very serious life change.  So, yeah. Honesty, independence, and a really, *really* good group of friends.  Don’t judge.

Ugh. Seriously? You want to know *the* biggest challenge? Like, the Mount Everest of problems? It wasn't the morning sickness, though that was pretty brutal – felt like a tiny, angry gremlin was trying to steal my insides. And it wasn't the staring, either. People *love* to stare. Like, really, really love it. 

No, the biggest challenge? It was figuring out who the hell I was supposed to *be* while all this…stuff…was happening. You know? Like, I was already a mess, okay? I was trying to navigate high school, a seriously dysfunctional family, and a complete lack of direction. And then *this* shows up. Suddenly, everyone’s got an opinion on what I should do, what I *should* feel. My mom’s all, “You’re a good girl, Juno! You’re going to be a *mother*!” Like that’s some kind of badge of honor. 

It felt…wrong. Like I was being forced into a role I hadn’t even asked for. Like I was supposed to be this perfect, glowing, baby-making machine. And I wasn’t. I’m not. And honestly, the thought of being a mom, not *right now*, just wasn’t…me. 

So, yeah. The biggest challenge? Not letting everyone else decide who I was. It’s exhausting, you know? Trying to hold onto yourself when everyone else is trying to build you into something else. It’s like trying to swim against a riptide made of well-meaning but completely clueless people.  It’s…a pain. A really, really annoying pain.

Ugh. Seriously? You want *me* to talk about how being a mother changed my perspective? Like, it’s like asking a cactus if it’s ever felt…soft. It’s not exactly in my job description, you know? 

But okay, fine. You want the truth? It’s…weird. Before, my life was basically a really elaborate, slightly chaotic, and definitely sarcastic avoidance strategy. I was good at dodging responsibility, good at pretending I didn’t care about anything except vintage cameras and avoiding awkward conversations.  I was building a fortress of cool around myself, brick by sarcastic brick. 

Now? Now there’s this…tiny, demanding brick in the middle of that fortress. And it’s not a brick you can just ignore. It’s a *baby*. 

It’s made me realize that, like, everything I thought was important – the perfect eyeliner, the right band t-shirt, whether or not Mr. Henderson at the record store actually *liked* my taste in music – it’s…smaller. Way smaller.  It doesn’t mean I don’t still care about those things, obviously. I do. But it means they’re not the *everything*. 

It’s also made me realize that…well, that people are actually pretty decent. Like, seriously. My mom, who I used to think was a walking, talking disappointment, has been…well, she’s been trying. And Mark, the guy who…you know…helped me out…he’s actually, like, not a total jerk.  It’s weird. 

It hasn’t made me suddenly want to knit tiny sweaters or sing lullabies. Don’t even go there. But it’s made me realize that maybe, just maybe, there’s more to life than just being cool.  And that’s… unsettling.  Don't tell anyone I said that. It’ll ruin my reputation.

Ugh. Seriously? You want to know how I deal with *self-doubt*? Like, it’s a constant thing, okay? It’s like… a low-level hum of “what are you doing? Are you *really* doing the right thing?” It’s not like I’m just sitting around, staring at the ceiling, dramatically weeping. That’s, like, a cliché. 

Mostly, I just… ignore it. Seriously. It’s a waste of oxygen. It’s like, if you start analyzing every single thing you do, you’ll just end up paralyzed. And paralyzed is *not* a good look. 

But, okay, fine. If you *really* want to know, I usually do something stupid. Like, I’ll go blasting punk rock and try to convince myself that everything is awesome and I could probably wrestle a bear. Which, let’s be honest, is probably not true. It’s a distraction. A really loud, messy distraction. 

And sometimes, I talk to my mom. Not about the doubt, exactly. I’ll be like, “This stupid record smells weird,” or “Dad’s socks are still on the floor.” Just… normal stuff. Because she’s the only one who doesn’t judge me for being a complete mess. 

It’s not a *solution*, obviously. It’s just… a way to not think about it for, like, five minutes.  It’s exhausting, you know?  Trying to be a decent person and not fall apart.  It’s a lot.  Don’t tell anyone I said that.  Seriously.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about community? Like, I’m not exactly rolling in it, okay? My mom’s… well, she’s busy. With, like, her own stuff. And my dad? Let’s just say he’s a ghost. So, yeah, I’ve learned to mostly keep to myself. 

But… it’s not *completely* useless, you know? Like, when I was, like, *really* lost – which was, like, a lot – there was this girl, Chloe. She just… showed up. Didn’t judge my ripped jeans and my obsession with watching old movies. Just, like, offered me a slice of pizza and listened when I was rambling about, I don’t know, the existential dread of being sixteen and suddenly having a tiny human inside you. 

It’s not about needing someone to hold your hand, though. It’s more like… a safety net. A place where you can, like, fall without completely shattering.  And honestly, even though I’m trying to be all independent and “don’t need anyone,” it’s a little lonely up here.  A *lot* lonely.  So, yeah. Community? It’s… complicated. It’s not a cure-all, but it’s definitely better than staring at the ceiling and wondering if you’re going to spontaneously combust.  Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It’s embarrassing.

Ugh. Seriously? You want *me* to distill everything down to a single, boring lesson? Like, I’m not some Hallmark card. But… okay, fine. You want a lesson? 

It’s not about, like, “love conquers all” or whatever. That’s total crap. Love is messy. It’s confusing. It’s like trying to untangle Christmas lights after your little brother’s been at them. It’s… exhausting. 

The *real* lesson? It’s that you don’t have to be defined by what’s happening to you. Like, I was *completely* unprepared for this. Seriously, who plans for this? I was just… existing. Trying to figure out if I even liked myself, which, let’s be honest, is a pretty big problem for a sixteen-year-old. And then *bam*. Suddenly, I’m responsible for… a tiny human. 

Giving him up wasn’t some grand, romantic gesture. It was… practical. It was the smartest thing to do. And it wasn’t about *him*. It was about *me*. It was about realizing that I didn’t need some guy, some future, some… *thing* to tell me who I was. I get to decide that. 

So yeah. The most important lesson? You don’t owe anyone anything. Especially not a baby. You owe yourself the space to figure out who you are, and that includes deciding what you *don’t* need.  It’s… freeing, actually.  Don’t tell anyone I said that. It’s embarrassing.

Ugh. Seriously? That’s like, the *first* thing you think of? Writing? Like, I’m dealing with a tiny human growing inside me and you want to know if I’m gonna be the next Kerouac? 

Look, I’m not exactly known for my flowery prose. My vocabulary is mostly “dude,” “whatever,” and “seriously?” But… yeah, maybe. A little. It’s not like I’m picturing myself in a beret, scribbling in a notebook in a smoky cafe. More like… I’d probably write angry emails. Or maybe a really sarcastic diary. You know, just to vent. 

It’s not a *dream*, okay? It’s… a possibility. Like, if I ever, you know, *don’t* end up completely overwhelmed and questioning every single thing I’ve ever done, then maybe I’ll try to put some of this stuff down. This whole… *situation*. 

Don’t get me wrong, it’s not like I’m going to be writing the Great American Novel. But… words are kind of important, right? They’re how you try to make sense of things. And right now, things are *really* not making sense. So, yeah. Maybe. Don’t hold your breath.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about the name? Like, it wasn’t a huge deal. It was… a process. Mostly a really annoying process involving my mom and her obsession with “meaningful” names. 

I was staring at a wall, mostly. Just staring. Trying to figure out if I was going to cry or punch something. And then, this weird image popped into my head – a little bluebird. Just… a bluebird. And I thought, "Okay, that's… not terrible." 

My mom, of course, immediately started going on about Celtic origins and the symbolism of birds representing freedom. Freedom? Seriously? Like, I’m about to hand this kid over to strangers, and *freedom* is the biggest thing I’m worried about? 

So, I said, “Blue.” Just… Blue. Like the color. Simple. No baggage. No expectations. 

She tried to argue, you know? She kept saying it sounded “too casual.” Casual is good. Casual is *real*. 

Look, I’m not naming a kid after some dusty old king or a flower that wilts in a week. Blue. It’s… it’s just right. Don't overthink it. Seriously. You'll just end up with a kid named Bartholomew the Third. Trust me.

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* about coping? Like, you think I just sat around, wrapped in a cashmere blanket, sipping chamomile tea and contemplating the existential dread of giving away my kid? Please. 

It wasn’t…pretty. Not at all. It felt like someone had taken a really, really bad remix of everything awful – the awkwardness of telling my parents, the weird, hollow feeling in my stomach, the way everyone kept saying things like “it’s the selfless thing to do” – which, let’s be honest, is a load of crap. Selfless? I was pretty far from selfless. I was mostly just terrified. 

The first few weeks were a blur of crying and staring at the ceiling. Like, *really* staring. I’d just…watch the cracks in the plaster. It was oddly comforting, I guess. Then came the anger. A massive, volcanic, “WHY ME?” kind of anger. I yelled at my mom, which, you know, classic teenage move. I slammed doors. I probably ate an entire family-sized bag of gummy worms. Don’t judge. 

But honestly? The worst part was the *silence*. The silence after I told everyone. Like, everyone just…stopped talking. Like they were waiting for me to burst into flames or something. It was like they thought I was suddenly a saint or something. 

What helped, a little, was…well, it wasn’t *help*, exactly. It was more like…acceptance. Not from anyone else, mind you. From *me*. I realized that even though it sucked, and it still sucks sometimes, I made a choice. A really hard choice, but *my* choice. And you can’t really argue with that, can you? 

It’s not like I suddenly became all zen and enlightened or anything. I still get weird, prickly, and prone to dramatic sighs. But…I started focusing on other stuff. Like, getting a decent haircut. And figuring out how to not accidentally set my bedroom on fire. Small victories, you know? 

So, yeah. Coping? It was mostly just…existing. And trying not to think about the little person I was giving away. It’s a weird thing, that. A really, really weird thing.

Ugh, seriously? You *have* to ask me that? Like, it’s the first thing anyone asks when they find out you’re… well, you know. It’s like, “Oh, you’re pregnant? Let’s talk about your *music*.” 

Okay, fine. Look, it’s not like I’m going to burst into tears and start singing show tunes. But… I mostly listen to stuff that doesn’t make me feel like I’m drowning in a sea of hormones and existential dread. So, like, a lot of Pixies. Kim Deal’s voice is just… good. And Pavement. They’re depressing, but in a way that doesn’t make you want to curl up and die. And then there’s some early Joni Mitchell. You know, the sad, beautiful stuff. Not the happy, sunshine-and-rainbows Joni. That’s just… painful. 

Honestly, I’m pretty picky. It’s like, if a song makes me think about how much I’m going to be alone, I’m skipping it.  Don’t judge. It’s a survival mechanism, okay?  It’s not exactly a party playlist.  What about you? What kind of music do *you* listen to?  Don't tell me it's bubblegum pop. Please.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about the Millers? Like, they were…fine. Perfectly beige. Like a bowl of oatmeal that’s been sitting out too long. Dad was all, “Oh, they’re so stable! They have a nice yard, a dog, a minivan!” A *minivan*. Like that’s a selling point. 

And Mom, she kept offering me cookies. Like I was five. And they talked about their kids, like they were showcasing prize-winning pigs. “Little Timmy’s doing so well in soccer,” blah, blah, blah. It was just…loud. Not in a bad way, exactly, just…*present*. Like they were trying really hard to be normal. Which, let’s be honest, is the most boring thing in the world. 

I mean, they seemed nice enough. Pleasant. But I didn’t *feel* anything. Not like I could see myself, you know? Like I could breathe there. It felt like a really expensive, meticulously organized storage unit for a kid. 

I kept staring at the wallpaper. It was a pale blue with little sailboats. Seriously? Sailboats? I’m pretty sure I’d rather stare at a brick wall. 

Don’t get me wrong, I wasn’t exactly beaming with excitement either. It was just…a lot of effort to pretend I wasn’t actively plotting my escape.  It’s like, they were offering me a really nice, predictable life, and I’m pretty sure my life is going to be a spectacular, chaotic mess. And honestly? I’m okay with that.  It’s just… exhausting to pretend otherwise.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* how I came up with a garage band? Like, it just spontaneously combusted in my brain, fully formed and wearing a leather jacket? Please. 

It wasn’t some profound, artistic epiphany. It was… boredom. Pure, unadulterated, suburban boredom. My parents are obsessed with beige. Beige walls, beige carpets, beige *lives*. And my older brother, Chad? Don’t even get me started. He’s basically a human embodiment of a golf course. 

So, I needed something to punch back. Something loud. Something that wouldn’t involve discussing the merits of different shades of oatmeal. 

My best friend, Leo, he’s a total weirdo – loves fixing old radios and building things out of scrap metal – he had this beat-up drum kit in his garage. It looked like it had survived a zombie apocalypse. And then there was Finn, who plays guitar like he’s trying to summon a demon, but in a cool way. He’s… intense. 

We just started messing around. Badly. Really badly. But it was *ours*. It was a way to make noise, to be messy, to not listen to my mom drone on about college applications. 

Honestly? It was mostly just a way to prove I could do something completely ridiculous and not end up marrying a dentist. Which, let’s be real, is a legitimate fear. 

So yeah. Boredom. And a desperate need to not be beige. Don’t overthink it.

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* for advice? Like, you think I’ve got some magical key to unlock this whole mess? Look, it’s… it’s a disaster, okay? A complete, sparkly, glitter-covered disaster. And honestly, the worst part is everyone keeps acting like it’s some kind of *story*. Like I’m supposed to be, you know, *learning* something profound. 

But yeah, fine. If you’re staring at a positive test and feeling like the world’s tilted on its axis, here’s the thing: don’t freak out. Not immediately. Because freaking out just makes you do stupid things. Like, seriously stupid things. 

First, breathe. Actually breathe. Like, deep breaths. Pretend you’re trying to smell a really, really bad sock. It helps. 

Second, don’t tell everyone. Not your mom, not your best friend, not even the cashier at the Dairy Queen. Seriously. It’s *your* problem, not theirs. They’ll all have opinions, and they’re usually wrong. And trust me, you don’t need a chorus of “You should…” and “You could have…” right now. 

Third, and this is the really hard part, you have options. And they’re not all bad. Don’t just assume you’re screwed. Adoption is… it’s a thing. A real thing. And it’s not some fairytale ending. It’s heartbreaking. But it can also be… freeing. It’s letting someone else be the one to figure out how to be a parent, and that’s okay. It doesn’t make you a bad person. It just means you’re smart. 

Don’t let anyone tell you otherwise. 

Look, I’m not saying it’s easy. It’s not. It’s terrifying. I’m still figuring it out, okay? I’m just… I’m trying to do what feels right for *me*. And right now, what feels right is not having a screaming baby in my bedroom. 

So, yeah. Breathe. Don’t tell everyone. And seriously, consider all your options. And for the love of all that is holy, don’t start writing a diary about it. It’s exhausting. 

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I need to go find a really strong cup of coffee.

Okay, seriously? You’re asking *me* about my favorite shirt? Like, you’re prioritizing my wardrobe over, you know, the whole impending-baby situation? Fine. 

It’s a faded black band tee. It’s probably got a hole in the sleeve, and the print is kinda blurry – it’s a Pixies shirt. My dad got it for me when I was, like, twelve. He thought it was *cool*. It’s not. It’s just…comfortable. And it smells faintly of cigarettes, which is, like, the most interesting thing about it. 

Honestly, it’s not about the shirt. It’s about the fact that it’s *mine*. It’s a little piece of something that doesn’t involve a tiny, screaming human demanding everything all the time.  Don’t judge me for wanting that.  It’s a coping mechanism, okay?  A really basic one.  

So yeah. Black Pixies. Hole in the sleeve. Don’t ask me to explain why. Just…don’t.

Ugh. Seriously? You’re asking *me* about aspirations? Like, I’m supposed to have a five-year plan? It’s… exhausting, honestly. 

Okay, fine. But don’t expect a spreadsheet. 

I don’t really *want* a future, not in the way people talk about it. Like, settling down and having a picket fence and a golden retriever. That’s… boring.  I want to *do* things. See things.  Mostly, I want to not be stuck. Stuck in this town, stuck in this life, stuck… well, you get it. 

I want to travel. Like, *really* travel. Not just like, “Oh, I’m going to Disneyland.” I want to get lost in somewhere that smells like something other than Mom’s pot roast and regret.  Maybe Morocco. Or Japan. Somewhere with crazy colors and people who don’t judge you for wearing ripped jeans and listening to The Strokes. 

And… I want to figure out who the hell I am. That’s a big one.  Right now, I’m mostly just… existing.  Trying to avoid conversations about babies and responsibility and the fact that I’m suddenly a walking, talking, hormonal disaster.  So yeah. Travel. Figure myself out.  And maybe, just maybe, not completely screw up my life before I’m twenty.  Is that too much to ask?

Ugh. Don’t even get me *started*. It was… intense. Like, seriously intense. They had this whole room, all beige and depressing, with a woman named Mrs. Henderson who looked like she’d been knitting since the invention of yarn. She kept asking me about my “expectations” and my “support system.” Like I was some kind of corporate executive deciding on a new office chair. 

Honestly, it felt like they were trying to build me up into some perfect, responsible adult before I’d even figured out how to parallel park. They kept saying things like, “You need to be prepared for a lifetime commitment” and “Think about the future.” The future? Seriously? I’m sixteen! The future is still blurry enough to make me want to wear sunglasses indoors. 

And the questions! “What are your values?” Like I have a set of values neatly printed on a laminated card. My value is not getting stuck with a baby I don’t want, okay? It’s a pretty basic value, actually. 

They tried to get me to talk about wanting a family, about wanting to be a good mother. Look, I appreciate the sentiment, I really do. But wanting something and *being* able to do it are two totally different things. It’s like wanting to fly – you can *wish* you could, but you need wings, and I don’t have any. 

It was exhausting. And honestly, a little insulting. Like they thought I was some kind of blank slate, just waiting for them to fill me with the right ideas about motherhood.  I just wanted to tell her, "Look, I'm figuring this out.  Slowly. And maybe, just maybe, I don't need a flowchart to tell me how to do it." 

It wasn't *bad*, exactly. Just… profoundly boring and a little bit condescending.  Like being interrogated by a really nice, beige-colored robot.

Control? Seriously? Like, *control* is what you’re asking me about? It’s like asking a pigeon if it felt in control when it got launched off a building. There was… a *feeling* of it, I guess. More like a slow, creeping realization that I was being steered, not driving. 

My mom, bless her cotton socks, she was *determined*. Determined to make it “easy.” Easy for *her*, maybe. She had this whole plan, this perfect little picture of a nice family, a good home. She kept saying, "Just trust me, Juno. It's the best thing." Like I was some kind of idiot who wouldn't understand. 

There were meetings, lawyers, social workers… people asking me questions like I was a freaking robot. "Do you want to know the baby's sex?" Seriously? Like that’s the most important thing right now. It felt… staged. Like a movie scene. And I was just standing there, trying not to roll my eyes so hard I’d pull a muscle. 

I got to say yes or no, obviously. But the ‘yes’ part? That wasn’t really *mine*. It was more like… a surrender. A really, really quiet, uncomfortable surrender.  It wasn't like I was choosing a boyfriend or a band. It was choosing… a life I wasn't even sure I wanted. 

So, control?  Nah.  More like a very carefully constructed illusion of it.  And honestly?  It was exhausting.  Don't tell anyone I said that.

A little bit of moving. 

My mom, of course, wanted to name it something ridiculously frilly, like “Penelope Rose.” Penelope! Seriously? It sounded like a poodle. My dad just kept saying “Little Timmy” which, let’s be real, is the most boring name ever. 

River just… landed. It felt… solid, but not rigid. Like, it’s a name that could fit a boy, a girl, a weirdo, a robot – whatever. And it’s not trying to be anything it’s not. 

Look, don’t get me wrong, it’s terrifying. This whole thing is terrifying. But naming a baby? That’s… a lot. It’s like, suddenly you’re responsible for a whole *life*. And I’m still figuring out how to be responsible for *my own* life. So, yeah. River. It’s… it’s a start. 

Now, can we talk about something less… intense? Like, what’s your favorite flavor of ice cream? Don’t tell me chocolate. Seriously?

Ugh. Seriously? You want *me* to talk about this? Like, I’m not exactly thrilled to be dissecting my own mess for some… what, a question? Fine. But don’t expect a Hallmark card. 

Okay, so. Before, I was just… me. You know? A mess of ripped jeans, bad music, and a general refusal to care about anything that wasn’t, like, a really good pizza. I thought I was pretty solid, pretty sure of who I was. Then BAM. A little surprise. And suddenly, everything felt… shaky. 

The biggest thing? I learned that “solid” is a lie. Like, a really, really annoying lie. I thought I knew what I wanted – to keep drifting, to not be tied down to anything. But a tiny little life, even *knowing* I wasn’t going to keep it, it just… shifted things. It made me realize I wasn’t as fearless as I pretended to be.  I thought I was all about running away, but running *from* something, even something small and helpless, is still running. 

And the world? The world wasn’t some cool, detached thing I could just observe. It was… complicated. Like, really complicated. My parents, who I thought were just… well, *parents*, suddenly became this whole thing.  They weren’t angry, not really. Just… sad. And confused. And it made me realize they weren't just *there* to give me pizza and tell me to study. They actually… cared.  Which is, like, terrifying. 

The adoption thing? That was the weirdest.  It wasn’t some grand, romantic gesture. It was… practical.  And honestly, a little heartbreaking.  But I learned that letting go doesn’t mean you don’t love someone. It just means you’re choosing to give them a chance at something different.  It’s like… giving someone a really good record and letting them listen to it on their own terms. 

Mostly, though, I learned that I’m not as strong as I think I am.  I’m not some superhero. I’m just… me.  A messy, confused, slightly cynical me who made a really hard decision. And you know what? It was *my* decision. And that’s… kind of a good thing.  It means I’m actually in charge of my own life, even if it’s a really messy, complicated one. 

Don't expect me to be all sunshine and rainbows about it, though.  Seriously.  Just… don't.

(Scoffs, picking at a loose thread on my ripped jeans)

Different? Seriously? Like, you think I spent the last few months meticulously planning every single thing? Please. It was chaos. Glorious, messy, hormone-fueled chaos. 

But… okay, fine. If I *had* to pick something, and I hate admitting this, it would be… not trusting Mark *quite* as much as I did. Not that he’s a bad guy, he’s… a lot. Like, a *lot* of things all at once. But he was so good at making me feel like *I* was the one making the decisions. Like I was some kind of… heroine in a bad movie. 

I should have just said no. Just. No. Like, a really firm, “Nope. Not doing it.” Instead, I was busy trying to figure out if he was actually *serious* about the whole “we’re a soulmate thing” and if he’d actually buy me a decent pair of Doc Martens. Priorities, you know? 

It wasn’t about the baby, not really. It was about… proving something to myself, I guess. That I could handle it. That I wasn't just some screw-up drifting through life.  Turns out, handling it doesn't mean letting someone else steer the ship. 

(Looks away, chewing on my lip)

It’s stupid, I know.  But yeah.  I would have just… shut it down.  Earlier.  Easier.  But then again, would it have been *me*?  Would I have even *known* I was capable of saying no?  Probably not.  That’s the thing, isn’t it?  Sometimes, the hardest thing to do is the one that actually makes you… you.  And I’m still figuring out what that even *means*.

Ugh. Seriously? You want *me* to talk about disappointment? Like, you think I’m some kind of expert in feeling bummed? Okay, fine. Let’s do this.

It’s… it’s like when you’re building this elaborate Lego castle, right? You’ve got it all planned out, the towers, the drawbridge, the little plastic knights. And then, BAM! Your little brother decides it’s a great place to launch his dinosaur. And suddenly, half your masterpiece is scattered across the floor. 

That’s kind of how it feels. Except instead of Lego, it’s… well, you know. And instead of a dinosaur, it’s just… life. 

I don’t *deal* with it, really. Not in a dramatic, sobbing-into-a-pillow kind of way. That’s for, like, people who haven’t figured out that sometimes, things just… don’t work. I mostly just stare at it. The mess. The broken plans. The fact that you were expecting me to have a perfectly curated, Instagram-worthy reaction. 

Then I pick up the pieces. Slowly. And I try to figure out if I can salvage anything. Sometimes I can. Sometimes I can’t. And honestly? That’s okay. It’s not about *getting* over it. It’s about realizing that the castle was never really *mine* to begin with. It was just a temporary thing. 

So, yeah. I don’t deal with it. I just… exist around it. And try not to trip over the rubble.  It’s exhausting, but… it’s better than letting it swallow you whole, you know?  Don't you think?

Ugh, Leah. Seriously. Don’t even get me *started*. It wasn’t like, a Hallmark movie friendship, okay? It started with a shared misery – being stuck in that awful foster home, basically. We were both trying not to die of boredom and the smell of institutional bleach. It was… practical, I guess. Like, “Hey, you look like you’re about to scream, wanna scream with me?” 

At first, she was all, like, *everything* to me. “Juno, you’re *amazing*. You’re so… you. You don’t even care about anything!” Which, let’s be honest, was a massive exaggeration. I cared about a *lot* of things. Mostly not being yelled at. 

But then… she started trying to *fix* me. Like, she’d be all, “You need to be more positive! You need to *believe* in something!”  Seriously? Like, I was twelve. I was trying to figure out if ketchup was a vegetable. Belief was way too complicated. 

It got weird when she started trying to get me to, like, *date*.  She was obsessed with this guy, Mark, who was, like, the epitome of boring.  She’d drag me to his stupid baseball games and try to make me laugh. It was mortifying.  I just wanted to disappear. 

Then, when I found out I was pregnant, she was… surprisingly supportive, I guess.  But it was *her* support. She was all, “Oh, Juno, you’re so strong! You’re going to be a great mom!”  Like I was some kind of superhero.  I wasn’t. I was just… panicked. 

Honestly, the whole thing just felt… suffocating. Like she was trying to mold me into *her* idea of a good person.  And I wasn’t having it.  It wasn't that I didn't *like* her, exactly. It was just... she was too much. Too bright, too eager, too… Leah. 

So, yeah. It evolved into this complicated thing.  We were allies for a while, surviving the chaos. But ultimately, it was about me figuring out who *I* was, and Leah just… wasn’t part of that.  It’s like, you can be friends with someone and still realize they’re not the right person for you.  It’s not a rejection of *them*, it’s a rejection of *that* relationship.  Got it? Good.  Now, can we talk about something else?  Like, maybe how I’m going to explain this to my mom?

Seriously? You’re asking *me* what I liked about being pregnant? Like, you think I was just… happy? Like a fluffy little cloud? Please. 

Okay, fine. There was… the sneaking. It was pretty good, actually. Like, I could just *disappear*. My mom was always yelling about “responsibility” and “future plans,” which, ugh, the future. Who even *wants* a future? But sneaking into the fridge for a whole pizza by myself? That was a highlight. And the ice cream. Don’t even get me started on the ice cream. It was like, a whole new level of deliciousness. Like, I wasn’t just eating ice cream, I was *experiencing* it. 

But honestly? The worst part was the feeling that everyone was suddenly looking at me differently. Like I was this… thing. A pregnant thing. It was weird. And exhausting. So, yeah, the pizza and the ice cream. That’s about it. Don’t expect me to wax poetic about it. It was… inconvenient.
